Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube is a nice game where you have to create paths by placing dice in order to move forward.
There are also many hidden paths that make the levels varied and exciting.

Frôjo
0
52 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2
Recommandé
24.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 juin 2014
Once a 4-level mod made as a puzzle platformer, Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube has gained a dash, a colon, and even a tagline. The remarkable thing about this mod-to-game is how polished and professional the entire package looks. Inspired by games like Portal and Minecraft, this game has carved itself a niche that makes it both familiar enough for players to try out, yet unique enough to keep players intrigued and interested.

One of the strongest things Qbeh-1 has going for it is the simplistic gameplay. It's very obviously inspired by early games, and eschews many of the trappings of modern gaming's superfluous complexities. Because of this streamlined gameplay loop - find block, place block, move on - it allows the puzzle design to shine. Rather than throw a substantial number of complicated puzzle mechanics at you, this game instead chooses to give you four basic concepts - building, powering, jumping, and traveling - and by combining them in various ways, can deliver challenges as simple as building a basic set of stairs to a complicated maze with no floor that must be travelled using synchronized floating paths, complete with a white-knuckled jump at the end after placing a power block near the end of the path. Puzzles start as being simple - its a tutorial that doesn't feel like a tutorial at all, which is commendable - but build and combine in ways where you end up scaling a tower with only a handful of blocks and a deep sense of satisfaction when you reach the top.

The art design is commendable. One of the most interesting art projects I ever had was to draw a still life using a single color - brown, and two shades, one light brown, and one dark brown. The point of the exercise was to force you to make your choices more meaningful, rather than rely on an explosion of various colors. In a way, Qbeh-1 replicates this exercise. Rather than rely on flashy explosions, the latest and greatest shader effects, models with tens of thousands of polygons, and other graphical gimmicks, it focuses on a narrow band of artistic effects, and then pulls it off with great success. The colors - stark whites and greys accented with bursts of vibrant colors - not only are visually appeasing next to each other, but also contrast nicely with the amazing skies; some of the best I've yet seen in games. I got distinct feelings of Mirror's Edge and how they used color to guide the player through the levels. The color palette here is similar, and I think Qbeh-1 pulls it off better due to how uncluttered the worlds appear compared to Mirror's Edge.

The sound and music design for Qbeh-1 is amazing, as it's simplicity not only fits the thematic elements perfectly, but because of the simplicity, it manages to achieve depth. Rather than attempt to wow you with orchestral suites or generic dub-step wub-wubs, the music is airy, dreamy, and light. It fits in perfectly not only with the levels - large buildings floating high in the atmosphere - but it also hits a sweet spot that so much of game music misses; it's unique enough to be noticed, but not catchy enough to become so immediately recognizable (much of World of Warcraft's music suffers from this) that it becomes quickly tedious. It serves its purpose precisely - as ambient background sound to draw you in, but never to distract you. It's almost childlike sound and instrument choices help to draw you into the exploration motif, and even still, some tracks have almost a dark feel to them, suggesting there may be more under the surface than what first seems to be the case.

As someone who does level design, the design of the levels was something that impressed me immensely. Visually, the levels were stunning - floating monolithic structures that combined the comforting feeling of symmetry along with enough asymmetry to still remain visually interesting. Each world has its own theme, and the themes blend perfectly into the levels - icicles hang overhead in the winter levels, empty calcareous shells of molluscs lay in pools in the water levels, dead leaves lay in corners in the wind levels. Because everything was uniformly scaled (and the borders on the cubes helped reinforce this), there was never a feeling of having to make ridiculous trick-jumps. You immediately got the sense of what was possible and what was not, based on distance and the world's physics. Rather than try to cheat the puzzles using tricky jumps or falls, the solutions felt fair, and ultimately felt rewarding by using your brain rather than trying to exploit the physics, jumping, or collision.

The story and theme is something that I specifically wanted to touch on, as I had seen some posts about there not being a story or anything resembling it. I'm not entirely sure that's the case, as there definitely feels like there's something going on below the surface. I think it might be safer to say that rather than a storyline, I felt like there was some overarching theme to the game.

Qbeh-1 feels like a dead world, in a lot of ways. There is beauty here, but also sadness. Presumably it was inhabited once - something or someone had to create those owl and elephant statues - but whoever it was is now gone. The player feels like, as he is exploring, he is inadvertently bringing this world back to life through his actions, either by literally building with red cubes, or by powering up devices with blue cubes. The notion of power - or the importance of it at least - is reinforced with the windmills and fans in Chapter 4.

Something else that is striking is the feeling and sense of an entropic world. An extremely basic (flawed, but works here) definition for entropy is the lack of order or structure - that in a closed system, energy flows out of organized and structured systems to leave them in a disordered and chaotic state. Qbeh-1 really has an entropic feeling to it - the idea that the world is gradually falling into an entropic state of disarray. Rooms are missing walls, floors, and ceilings, where blocks literally fall into the atmosphere. Even in areas where walls and floors are straight, the occasional cube will be out of place - sticking out a few cm, or perhaps tilted just a few degrees; clearly done on purpose by the designer for effect. Floors crumble beneath you as you walk on them. Perhaps the fans and windmills were an effort to make sure energy remaining in the system, holding it together as best as it could. And perhaps by our actions, and how we (in a way) organized the system, there is hope for this world after all.

Qbeh-1, overall, is an amazing example of a non-typical game that easily surpasses much of what would be considered more mainstream games, by virtue of the fact that everything is does, it does really, really well. Rather than be a jack-of-all-trades to attempt to appeal to everything while exceeding at nothing, Qbeh-1 excels at the simplistic gameplay that leads to complicated puzzles, stunning artistic theme, amazing music and sounds, and incredible level design that pulls all these elements together into a cohesive unit. It's a peaceful game that alternates some degree of timing puzzles with the slow and methodical exploration that allows you to play at your own pace. For those who enjoy exploration, each level also contains a golden pyramid pickup which are usually hidden in fiendishly clever places.

Developed using the Unity game engine, this is a game which is highly recommended, but I fear that it will slide under the radar for most gamers which I think is a tragedy. It's a great example of the ability to marry the puzzle genre with a more traditional first person genre, and still be successful without resorting to violence, being spoon fed a storyline, or the overly scripted gameplay which creates the illusion of cerebral choice, but actually offers none at all. Rather this game celebrates choice, exploration, and emergent problem solving in an environment which nurtures it.

Still great:2023!
 
Tundra - タンドラ
1,564 produits enregistrés
0
80 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante

Recommandé
4.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 mai 2015
Игру Qbeh игроки часто сравнивают с Portal’ом. Но это не совсем корректное сравнение, потому что обозреваемый проект больше похож на Q.U.B.E. Только воспринимается как своеобразное продолжение. Вместо перчаток, действующих на расстоянии, игроку нужно самостоятельно подойти к кубу и взять в руки. Принцип головоломок почти ничем не отличается. Нельзя сказать, что это плохо – в конце концов, неужели так много игроков ознакомилось с обоими проектами, чтобы заметить сходство? И это тоже ещё не основной аргумент: главное то, что Qbeh очень и очень красива, и воспринимается она с художественной точки зрения совсем по-другому.

Действие игры протекает в абсолютном «нигде». Перед вами лишь почти полностью разрушенная от времени бывшая, похоже, лаборатория, висящая в прямом смысле в воздухе. Зато виды вокруг открываются великолепные. Рассветы и закаты, солнечное чистое небо и ночные небесные сферы – только в отличие от наших земных условий все эти красоты не только над головой.

Игровые карты представляют собой небольшой лабиринт, по которому чаще всего можно пройти, только вооружившись разукрашенным кубиком. Их обычно на уровнях несколько и их можно установить в определённые места, чтобы создать или лесенку, или мост, или весьма странную конструкцию, которая и потребуется для прохождения. Сложность головоломок нарастает постепенно, а если вы играли в подобные игры и уже знаете их механику, то особых проблем игра не предоставит. Целью является добраться из одного конца карты до другого. Концовка уровня – белоснежный дверной проём, который вам и предстоит найти. А чтобы облегчить ваши страдания после того, как вы в очередной раз сорвётесь вниз и начнёте уровень заново, где-то на полпути к выходу расставлены контрольные точки в виде стилизованных под петроглифы сов.

С каждым новым уровнем вам встретятся граздо более сложные задачи и попадутся новые кубы, обладающие иными свойствами. Если поначалу игра может показаться однообразной из-за того, что геометрически первые уровни почти одинаковы, то далее усложнённые и оригинальные задачи устроят вам зарядку для ума.

Игра также предоставляет вам весьма сложную задачу, поставленную параллельно вашей основной цели. На каждом из тридцати шести уровней спрятаны предметы, которые весьма трудно собрать. Если вы любите осматривать каждый угол, в том числе похожий, скорее, на баг, то эта игра для вас. Достижения в ней тоже дают лишь за сборы этих пирамидок. Это печально, потому что достижения в таких играх положительно сказываются на желании игроков двигаться дальше. В том же Q.U.B.E. достижения отсыпали за каждый сектор и за некоторые головоломки, что было отличным поощрением. Игрок понимал, что игра оценила его старания по достоинству.

Естественно, что и сюжета тут в общем-то и нет. Просто начинаете новую игру, загружаетесь и – вуаля! – вы уже на игровой карте, где разбирайтесь сами. И это не так уж и плохо: основная цель этой игры именно в прохождении головоломок, которые далеко не очевидны с первого взгляда. Только финал даст вам некоторые знания о том, для чего вы всё это проходили. Хотя всё равно это серьёзным сюжетом назвать нельзя.

Зато тут хорошо поработали не только дизайнеры уровней, но и художники окружения. Здесь достаточно много своеобразных петроглифов и иных достопримечательностей, сделанных людьми древности. Идолы, искусно покрытые резьбой деревянные статуи и сами разноцветные кубы – все они создают даже некоторую атмосферу. Конечно, эта игра не такая мрачная, как, скажем, симулятор ходьбы NaissanceE, но это и к лучшему: полумузейная, полудомашняя атмосфера – это что-то не такое уж и обычное. Качество изображения «небесного» окружения уже было затронуто, но и сами уровни выполнены весьма изящно.

Музыка же не выделяется так же, как дизайн. Общую картину, однако, это вряд ли портит. В конце концов, если не будет звучать музыка, то вы будете слышать пение птиц, тихое журчание воды и шелест листьев деревьев, растущих в явно маленьких для них клумбах, висящих в воздухе вместе со всей игровой картой. В остальном же Qbeh – своеобразная головоломка, пути решения которой чаще всего неявны, что здорово. Приправлена игра интересным игровым дизайном, множеством секретов и отличными видами. Рекомендуется любителям Q.U.B.E.’о-подобных игр, а также игрокам, которым нравится медитативный игровой процесс. Всё это Qbeh дать вполне способна.

Подписывайтесь
 
Drunkēn Word.Maśter

1
Non recommandé
5.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 juin 2017
Very slow movement speed, "puzzles" based on parkour and dexterity rather than actual thinking (and no quicksaving, so if you fail you're set back about five minutes), and puzzles based on finding hidden objects rather than actual thinking.

The game does a poor job at communicating the puzzles to players:

* Very unclear connections, SO MANY "mystery buttons".
* You can look on the ground (sometimes) for connections leading into devices, but they don't change color when the device is activated (like an antline in Portal), so it's hard to tell whether the button is actually pressed. They're also nearly the same color as the walls and floors anyways, so you really have to squint to follow them.
* It doesn't help that the game intentionally hides buttons.
* ...as well as the cubes you require to solve them. It's possible to look at a puzzle, find it to be impossible, but then look in a random crevice you didn't think to look into before and find like fifteen red cubes that would have trivialized the puzzle.
* A number of puzzles have BLATANT unintended solutions.
* A number of puzzles don't even use anywhere close to all the cubes.
* Buttons look exactly the same as a completely different puzzle element (red cubes)
* World 2 is very dark for no discernible reason. I could hardly see what I am supposed to do.
* Because there's no quicksaving, few checkpoints, and very very long screen transitions (why?), it's really hard to justify experimentation in the puzzles.

Breaks a number of like, Puzzle Design 101 things:
* Red herrings.
* Trapping situations.
* Hiding stuff.
* Execution-based puzzles.
* Experimentation discouraged.
* No difficulty curve - the harder levels are hard because they have more parkour and hidden objects, not more thinking.

Took a look at the level editor.
* It's a grid/voxel based game, but nothing snaps to the grid by default?
* Doors have the complete wrong origin - if you use grid snap on them they either hover half a unit above the ground or sink half a unit below it.
* Very hard to sketch out puzzles with the ease of something like Portal 2's Puzzlemaker. It takes forever to even get a room set up, never mind an actual puzzle. Controls are very clunky.
 
quat
147 produits enregistrés
4
16 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
22.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 mars 2022
Produit reçu gratuitement

*Note that one achievement is broken in the latest version - you need to downgrade to the 1.1.3a beta branch, which can be done through the Steam client, to obtain it

My Playtime: 22.3h (100% achievement, finished the game twice)
My First Playthrough: 18.3h
Grindy Achievement(s): No.
Optional Achievement(s): Yes (15 achievements).
Difficult Achievement(s): No.

Intro
Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube is a puzzle-platformer game about cubes. You have to pick up cubes and place them on yellow tiles to make a pathway to finish the level. The game has 30+6 levels in total, which will increase in difficulty and be more reliant on your platforming skills as you play.

Pros:
- 30+6 levels
- Checkpoints are abundant
- Some areas can be cleared in different ways

♥♥♥♥:
- It can be hard to find all cubes and hidden tiles, preventing progression
- It's hard to pick up cubes beneath your feet
- Bug where your cube can disappear if you click on it too fast

Specs
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

Should you buy this game?
Yes.
If you like puzzle-platformer games and don't mind some challenge, especially the ones that are reliant on platforming skills, buy this game at a sale. Casual players might have trouble finishing the bonus levels due to the difficulty.


In-Depth Review

Visuals
Everything in the game mostly consists of cubes that are stacked on top of each other. There are other objects like totems that have different sizes, but they only serve as a decoration to spice up the place. However, I found the lighting to be inconsistent - it was very dark when you are inside an area full of cubes, and bright when you are outside. I had to manually change my screen's brightness to adjust to it.

The Game
Gameplay
The game is a puzzle-platformer at its core. It's similar to Portal, but instead of a portal gun, you'll have cubes instead. You need to pick up cubes that are scattered around the area and place them in the yellow tile(s) to create a pathway to go to another area. Since cubes are limited, you need to make sure that you place them efficiently. Cubes with different mechanics will be introduced after 6 levels, increasing the difficulty as you play.

It can be hard to learn the controls at first. I didn't know that you can place a cube next to another cube without waiting for the game's prompt. I also didn't notice the green outline when you are about to remove the cubes - I kept on taking out the cube that I was standing on as a result. These annoyances won't matter once you have familiarized yourself with the gameplay, but the game will keep on implementing new mechanics to keep you busy.

Some paths are just plain hidden from the normal eye. See that hole to the right? You are supposed to go that way, not to the door. 
Une capture d'écran de Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube
Par : aquatorrent


Most of the gameplay will revolve around clearing puzzles which can be hard to figure out. Cubes, paths, and even switches will be hidden behind walls and other cubes, and since the walls are made from the same-looking cubes, it can be hard to spot if you're not careful enough. Although you don't need to pick up all available cubes to clear some of the levels, some cubes are still mandatory to pick up, especially at the beginning of each level. That being aside, some puzzles are done cleverly. It was always satisfying to finish the levels once you know what to do.

Platformers
Although the first few levels are more focused on the puzzle, the other levels, especially the bonus ones, rely mostly on your platforming skills. There were a lot of instances when I wasn't sure that I was supposed to go through a path due to its difficulty, but I soon realized that I had no choice but to go that way anyway. The fact that I'm not good at predicting where my character was standing also makes it hard for me to walk through the narrow path that was made from the cubes, resulting in death. Luckily, checkpoints are abundant, and even if there are more than one difficult areas to navigate around the checkpoint, you can always go to the previous one to re-activate the newest one again.

The platforming section can discourage people from trying. The bonus levels become unpleasant to play because there are a lot of tricky jumps that you need to make, which force you to restart from the last checkpoint once you fail the jump. There might be another solution that you can try to clear the area, but it wasn't fun to redo everything from the last checkpoint until where you fail to try it, especially when you fail the jump repeatedly. My patience was growing thin at those levels and I became frustrated rather than enjoying them.

You need to use the cubes to construct a pathway to progress the area. 
Une capture d'écran de Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube
Par : aquatorrent


Length and Difficulty
I finished the game in 13h. I continued the game to finish the bonus content in 18.3h and spent the rest of my playtime replaying the game one more time to get the leftover achievements. You can get all achievements in one playthrough, but since two achievements are tricky, I decided to play it safe and do two runs instead. I actually regret it since I was exhausted from finishing the bonus levels.

The game is on medium-hard difficulty. The first few levels are easy and risk-free since you are expected to learn the mechanics. The difficulty will be ramped up at the last two worlds, which consists of 6 levels each, where a moving cube is introduced. A lot of free-fall areas will become more common, forcing you to be more precise and die every time you fail. Although I enjoyed the other levels, these two worlds weren't particularly enjoyable for me. The fact that the last, bonus world is way more difficult than the first 5 worlds also makes it discouraging to finish.

Problems
One of the levels in the second world has an FPS drop due to the snow effect. There is no way to turn the effect off despite it not affecting the level. Also, there is a bug where a cube will disappear if you click on it too fast - you need to look for the last yellow tile that you passed to find the cube. Lastly, it can be hard to pick up cubes that are beneath your feet.

Conclusion
Despite the annoyances, I still had a blast playing Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube. The first few levels were the best - it was fun figuring out how to make a pathway from so little cubes, and how to keep on arranging them to suit your needs. The platforming sections might give trouble later on, but it wasn't enough to stop me from playing and having fun with it. Besides, the game's cheap enough at a sale, and it offers more content and better quality than most games that were sold at that price. Fans of puzzle platformers will enjoy the game, and the introduction of the workshop feature means that you can spend more time enjoying it.

Follow our Curator page, Summit Reviews, to see more high-quality reviews regularly.
 
aquatorrent
590 produits enregistrés
7
22 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante

Recommandé
7.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 aout 2014
ブロック設置制限のあるMinecraftみたいな感じ。
空に浮かんだブロックで出来た所を出口を目指して進んでいく謎解きゲーム。
赤や白等のブロックを回収して設置し、白いワープゲートを抜けるとクリアー
途中にペンギン？何だアレは？な石造の側に寄ると途中セーブ
マップには必ず黄色い△が隠れてて、探すのも楽しい。大抵どうやって行くんだって所にある。

おススメの理由は、癒され具合がすんごかった。
ゲーム内の雰囲気もそうだけれど、BGMが良い。なんかアルファー波出てそうな感じの。
それ以外でも、風の音、虫の羽音や木のざわめき、ふと外を見るとどこまでも続く空が広がっていてマップを進めるたびに景色が変わっていく。
制限時間も無いし、敵もいない。あるのは冷たい感じのするフヨフヨ浮かぶブロックだけ

ストレス溜まった人にはおススメかも。あと、夏涼しい所でやると良し。私はとても良かった。
ただ、問題はやってると眠くなるZｚｚｚ

デモもあるので是非やってみて欲しい。かも。

あと、Oculus Rift にも対応してる。なんだ、アレだ。立体に見えるよってヤツ。
持ってないけど。
 
TK_tony

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante

Recommandé
21.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mai 2014
If you like what you see in the picture then you will like the game. It's a beutiful game with a great atmosphere to go with it. The game has five worlds with 6 levels on each one to go through, and each world gives new environmental touches, new puzzles to solve, and new unique cubes to play around with to solve those puzzles. And for those referencing the game to the 'free' one on Desura, while good, it doesn't even compare to the polish and content this game offers compared to the student project demo on desura. For the asking price i think QBEH-1: The Atlas Cube is a great purchase.

More info here: KSalue[www.ksalue.com]
 
FreakOrama
1,491 produits enregistrés

20 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 mai 2017
立方：擎天之盒

作为库存少有的解谜游戏，并且还是想玩才去买的，并不是加一
那么非解谜爱好者的我选择购买这游戏的原因，很大程度都是因为宣传片
宣传片中带来的空灵宁静的感觉我非常的喜欢，玩家在天空城中探索，前进。
这种感觉非常美妙，通过拾取不同功能的方块体，使用正确的方法，前往终点

游戏除了正常通关之外，还有完美通关这样的存在，一般通过取得所有地图中的立方体，
去走上游戏中看到的一处最初立方体不够上不去，或者缺少一种特定立方体的地方，亦或者单纯是一个比较隐蔽的地方取得一个类似于金字塔的金色发光物体收集品，最后通关
比较休闲的话，看看天空，走走跳跳也感觉非常不错，
后期遇到瓶颈可以打开自己喜欢的音乐，或者看看攻略视屏，休闲为主，解谜为乐
当完全探索完一个世界，取得了收集物通过关卡的成就感非常的棒！

http://www.bilibili.com/video/av11729463/
↑上面的是好友的游戏视频链接，对本游戏感兴趣有购买意愿的不妨看看，感谢支持！
 
Yuuka

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante

Recommandé
30.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 décembre 2014
Любите ли вы игры с кубами? Я люблю! Игра достойна места в антологии кубических игр - Blocks That Matter.
Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube чем-то походит на игры Portal, Portal 2, только без затхлой, кафельно-синтетической атмосферы гигантской подземной лаборатории, без монологов язвительно-циничной GLaDOS и без шуток старины Кейва Джонсона. Напротив, мы парим где-то в облаках, мы видим рассветы и закаты, смену времен года... И все это в полном одиночестве, без друзей и врагов. Собираем узорчатые кубы, имеющие разные функциональные и физические свойства, прокладываем ими дорогу к порталу на другую локацию. Слушаем музыку сфер, (привет, minecraft), наслаждаемся архитектурой каменных блоков, бродим в лабиринтах с естественным освещением, натыкаемся на чекпоинты в виде высеченных из камня сов, проявляем немного смекалки и попутно выискиваем потайные места где укрыты токены в форме пирамидок, время от времени подмечая на камнях изображение какого-то волшебника... Не скрою, кому-то это может быстро наскучить.
Ну, а я получил то что хотел и даже немного больше. Игра, безусловно, стоит своих денег. Разработчик обещает в будущем внедрить в игру редактор уровней.
 
Edison

1
Recommandé
20.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 novembre 2015
Красивая и приятная игра-головоломка.

Сопровождаемая великолепным саундтреком и, казалось бы, должна быть расслабляющей. По началу так оно и есть, головоломки решаются не сложно и игра проходится легко и не принужденно.
Но рано или поздно вы столкнетесь с тем тем местом, на котором будете постоянно падать и умирать, и так раз десять подряд. Вот тут то и начинается нервотреп, ведь игровой процесс сохраняется в определенных местах, это значит что вам после падения придется пройти половину уровня снова... что бы умереть еще раз. На там же месте.
Пройдя тот злополучный момент игровой процесс снова пойдет спокойно и не принужденно... до тех пор пока вы не застрянете еще раз. Но подобные ситуации не делают игру хуже, ни в коем случае.

Я очень рекомендую эту игру и не только любителям головоломок.
Она красивая, абстрактная и атмосферная.
В плане простого прохождения не сложная, но на каждом уровне спрятан "секрет", что бы его найти нужно иногда очень исхитриться.
Прекрасный саундтрек, позволяет лучше прочувствовать атмосферу игры и погрузиться в нее чуть ли не полностью!
 
FemurBreaker

10.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 décembre 2014
Qbeh-1. Score 9 / 10
Qbeh-1 is a tough 3D Puzzle Platformer

Collect Blocks that you then use to Build Access and unlock the Next Part of each level. Differently flavored Blocks have different Powers. Mix-match-pattern-repeat.

[Secret] There are hidden areas ! [/secret]

Move around this [Beautiful] floating 3D world and prepare to fall to your death while platforming. Most of the save points are reasonable... but when you intersprese platforming with puzzle elements sometimes I would quit when I fell too many times in a row. I got a Steam Achievement for this and it's called "Rage Quit". Self-explanatory No?

I swear I had Angina.

I enjoyed this game tremendously for over 10 hours.... and I will come back to this over the next year until I eventually finish it.
 
Kylo Ded

途中で落下したりするとチェックポイント地点から再スタートさせられたりと手厳しいんだけど、慣れてくると難なく進められるんだよね。
何といってもこのゲームの売りは「癒し」らしく、ステージ毎に空の風景が夕景、夜景と変わっていったり、ＢＧＭもとても良いと思いますよ。

Évaluation publiée le 15 mai 2014
Qbeh-1 is an awesome labor of love from developers Liquid Flower. After playing the free original game on Desura, this "prequel" game goes above and beyond the scope of what came before. Boasting almost 10x the content including levels, mechanics, and music, Qbeh-1 is a must have for those who love puzzles in a laid back setting and serene atmosphere.

I had the oppertunity to play this in beta form and seeing this launch on Steam makes me very happy. This game is for fans of Portal, Zelda (puzzles), a slight hint of Minecraft, and zen.

Non recommandé
18.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 mai 2015
In this first person puzzle game, you find cubes that do different things to help you navigate the floating worlds. There are four different colors of cubes: red (structure - build structures), blue (energy - power doors and platforms), purple (gravity - decrease gravity), green (growth? - moving platforms). The cubes can only be attached to certain areas of the world (yellow anchor points).

The gameplay isn't difficult, at least not initially. The first four worlds (there are six levels in each world) go by fairly quickly. The fifth world is a little more interesting as you have access to all the cubes and the designers mix up the puzzles appropriately. The sixth world, which feels like a bonus since it is accessed after the credits roll, is much more complex, yet still not difficult (in my opinon)

However, the joy is spent trying to find the secrets. Every level has one, and finding where they are hidden is what (in my opinion) is the fun in the game. It can be frustrating to get a vantage point in a level and see the yellow pyramid way back in the level. You also learn to "look" at the architecture to determine where the "best" hiding places may be. In the initial levels the roof isn't very accessible, but the later levels - particularly world six - that accessibility restraint is still true but there may be one (maybe two ways) to get up there using the blocks you have or gathering some and backtracking.

As I said, the game play isn't very difficult. It is a "zen-like" experience especially with the background music. The world is a lonely place, occupied by you alone. It does seem long for what it is and slightly underwhelming in retrospect.

Difficult to recommend as there are other games that are more "fun" to play.
 
YellowLab
1,324 produits enregistrés
0
19 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
126.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 juillet 2015
This game is made by liquid flower who can be found here http://qbeh-1.com/ . It seems to be their one and only game at the moment.

I liken the experience of this game to going for a walk along the beach. Everytime i do i have to climb along all the rocks. Don't ask me why. I just do. It's not like i'm exploring new territory, or achieving parkor greatness, even though in my imagination I am. Eventually we play that game where you try and get your feet as close as possible to the waves of the sea without getting wet. Silly games, but they make the walk along the beach enjoyable.

Qbeh-1 (pronounced cube negative one) is exactly like that, but in heaven. Why heaven has portal puzzles I'm not exactly sure? I guess it sure beats just playing the harp for eternity. Anyway as you go out and explore Minecraft heaven your imagination will start to tell you that you are achieving parkor greatness and thanks to the various magical cubes scattered around the place you probably are. On top of this you will eventually notice a game that the developers want you to play and that is don't touch the water (more about that later), but as you can see it's clearly the beach. Jump around the rocks and don't get your feet wet.

Story? None. Zip. Completely void of story. Let me see. There are windmills and fans, and trees and fountains, and carpet and native american owl totems. We have no idea who you are other than the fact that you suddenly appear through a entry portal and your objective is to find the exit portal. Your journey is aided by various cubes which help you build, defy gravity, activate devices or simply tranport you. The game is divided up into 6 worlds, the 6th you will only unlock when you have found all the golden pyramids. There is 1 golden pyramid hidden in each level in which to find them you will basically need a phd in puzzle mechanics or at least a youtube walk through. Each world has 6 levels and the 6th level contains a unique portal cube which will transport you to the next world. Each world has a unique theme from summer, winter, autumn etc and sort of feels like its in homage to the old mario games. If you find all the pyramids including those in world 6, the secret ending hints that there are many more worlds to come. This could be true as the developers have been promising a level editor feature to the game, but alas they have been promising that for a while and since the developers hardly respond to any comments in the Steam forum anymore it stands to reason why many have become somewhat disheartened.

Graphics are superb and the art and level design really makes this game for what it is. While the game doesn't ever reach levels of sheer brilliance, it does have the workings of becoming that if the developers really wanted it to. Personally I had some graphical issues with the trees in the game flickering black lines and there were a few places I found where I could trap myself in a block here and there or even make blocks disappear, but with these lingering teething issues aside, the graphics and game play in general was inspiring.

The Music and Sound has its moments. All the tracks are fitting in some way, but some seemed slightly grating at times or not as relaxing as others did. There was one track in the game which was truly magical to listen to and would entice you to want to explore the place. The track i'm referencing is found in world 1 level 6 and interestingly is the same one they use in their preview for the game.

While the ending feels somewhat lackluster and there is no story to be absorbed in here, and the level editor is somewhere in limbo, there is enough in interesting graphics and game play to give this a solid thumbs up. Various gamers have furthered amused themselves by entering a speedrun competition which you can only complete in if you download various speedrun mods. Again unfortunately another oversight of the developers not to include a timer in their game. Lastly it deserves a mention this 'don't get your feet wet achievement'. It seems to be only possible to achieve this if you complete the whole game in 1 sitting without touching the water, which basically requires you to never make a mistake. Needless to say with my two left feet and my absent minded ways coupled with my nervous twitching fingers, it's one I probably won't be getting in this lifetime.

If your ever in need of a good jump around the rocks session. This is a good game to get.

Vidéo YouTube™: Qbeh-1 Complete World 1 Lv 1-6 (All Pyramids) (No Water Touching) 
Vues : 89
3D block Puzzle game which requires you to make your way to the exit gate of each level. A secret hidden golden pyramid in each level and a extra achievement for those that can complete game without...

Recommandé
12.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 septembre 2015
Если вы терпеливы и можете, иногда, правильно позиционировать персонажа в FPS то вам понравиться эта пространственная головоломка.
Вам не будут стараться показать какую-то, за уши притянутую, историю. Не будет никакого обучения. Весь игровой процесс будет построен на вашей интуиции.
Уровни делятся на небольшие зоны, через которые вам нужно перейти, используя кубики со специальными возможностями. Один уровень проходиться за 10-30 мин (а их 36), в середине есть «чекпоинты», но сохранения только между уровнями.
Атмосферно вас стараются погрузить в состояние «умиротворения», бережно разбросав деревья с падающими листочками, спокойное музыкальное сопровождение. Главная заслуга игры – проработанность уровней. Придумать столь большие локации и просчитать прохождение игрока, требует больших трудозатрат. Не все получилось идеально хорошо – можно не найти место для куба, забыть нужный куб в прошлом районе. Но видя задачу – вы сразу понимаете решение или приходите к нему по мере начинания. 5 из 6 эпизодов открываются по мере прохождения, последний откроется, только если вы дополнительно соберете по трофею в каждом уровне – очень странное решение.
Но головоломки не сложные, способность новых кубов, порой, приводит в восторг. А если начинаете нервничать – послушайте фон и уравновесьте свой «Инь-Янь».
 
pestantium

Évaluation publiée le 9 juin 2015
Jogo com ótima trilha sonora, somando a ela bons gráficos e ambiência resulta em um jogo excelente do gênero puzzle 3D. Não é um jogo difícil, contudo em algumas partes complica pela precisão exigida dos saltos. O jogo é curto, pode ser finalizado em cerca de 2 horas, contudo encontrar todos os tokens para liberar o sexto mundo leva bem mais tempo e exige que algumas fases sejam jogadas mais de uma vez. No geral é um ótimo jogo, recomendo testar.

Évaluation publiée le 18 décembre 2014
居然没看到中文测评，不行，我看到这个画风就感觉好赞。

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
这是华丽的分割线
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

进商店就被bgm和画风吸引了，个人又很喜欢这种步行模拟解密类的游戏。所以就愿望单喜加一了。然后圣诞节顺利成章的用宝石拍得了游戏。玩起来也正如宣传片一样，个人非常喜欢。而且成就什么的也是强迫症患者的福音。断断续续玩的不多（我才不会告诉你们我智商不够用了呢）。毕竟是独立游戏嘛，有的地方还是有点小bug的，不过不影响游戏体验。至于优化问题嘛，玩久了我会有点掉帧，不知道为什么。总之我还是非常喜欢这款游戏的。

Recommandé
21.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 aout 2014
I discovered Qbeh-1 : The Atlas Cube on Desura a couple months before its release on Steam, and it caught my eye (mostly because I'm a puzzle-game weirdo), so obviously I bought it day one.

Under that intringuing name hides a true little gem of a game. As you start, you're thrown into this mysterious world, wandering around the corridors of ancient floating ruins lost in the sky (are you afraid of heights? Because it's full of true vertigo sensations up there).

Your mission is to find red glowing cubes (there are other colours later on), that can be placed on yellow walls and act as platforms to help you progress through the many levels.

The puzzles are well-designed, being not too hard, not to easy. You will progress with a challenge, but without frustration (but real puzzle gamers don't know frustration, anyways).

There are plenty of other cubes/colours with different powers and a nice learning curve that makes the game never boring and always full of surprises. A very interesting game mechanic : you cannot collect the cube you're standing on, or place a cube right under your feet while jumping - a technique that is well-known from the advanced Minecraft player.

I'd like to point out the fact that the game's optimisation is brilliant. Even on the lowest graphic settings, the textures are beautifully detailed (see my screenshots for further evidence), and my weak 2011 computer is very thankful of that.

The soundtrack is soft and sweet, just what you need for a relaxing puzzle game of this kind. The music won't disturb you, but it sure brings a lot to the general atmosphere!

There is a total of 5 worlds (actually 6, but pshhhhht, it's a secret). Each of them includes 6 levels, which may take you between 15 minutes up to a full hour, depending on your platforming skills. The bunch of well-hidden collectibles add to the replay value. Besides, a level Editor and a workshop are in the making!

Qbeh is my favourite 3D puzzleplatformer of this year, and you won't regret it at all if you're a fan of the genre.
 
Floyd
330 produits enregistrés
4
14 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
144.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 aout 2015
Beautiful little gem, really feels like a new world instead of a puzzle game with puzzle levels... Even though it really is just that.

The world is formed around blocky architecture with "natural" assets added to give it a more friendly and inviting environment. There's no story, dialogue, or text except for the main menu/chapter titles. Everything is presented in a manner that teaches the player what to do, instead of holding their hand/letting them walk around blindly.

The best aspect about this game is the... everything. As I said, it has no story, but with what it has (instead of what it's missing); the level design, the atmosphere, the music, the sound design, the HUD, the graphics, it hits the right note on every one of these.

I found myself smiling and feeling a sense of wonder and calmness throughout the levels, but it knows how to be a tad more serious/somewhat challenging at times as well.

As I mentioned, the game is missing something that's keeping it from being even more. I could probably say that a story would improve the experience for me, but if it weren't done correctly, it may ruin the already wonderful experience it gives.

For such a short game, I'm probably writing too much or more than such a simple game warrants, but I think everyone should consider playing this for its atmosphere and sound design. The water sounds really wet, the wind sounds really windy, and the cubes sound really cubey. Just play it for the experience, not for challenge or story.

It made me happy.
 
Beepin

Évaluation publiée le 28 mai 2014
Mit magischen Würfeln, von denen es verschiedene Typen gibt, müsst ihr Rätsel lösen und euch euren Weg durch rätselhafte Ruinen bahnen. Die Aufgaben fordern sowohl euren Verstand als auch euer Geschick und wenn ihr den beschwerlichen Weg an die Spitze eines dieser rätselhaften Gebilde gemeistert habt und den Ausblick genießt, dann macht sich ein wohliges Gefühl der Genugtuung breit. Auf eine Geschichte hat man zwar erneut verzichtet, aber das tut der Magie dieser herrlichen Reise keinen Abbruch, denn das Zusammenspiel der minimalistischen Ästhetik der Welten und die bezaubernde Musik von Launchable Socks erzeugen auch so eine geradezu mystische Atmosphäre.

QBEH-1: The Atlas Cube ist ein Prequel zu QBEH, das wiederum ein Studentenprojekt war und auf Desura kostenlos verfügbar ist.

Wer es lieber ausführlich mag, der findet mein komplettes Review auf http://polygonien.de/2014/05/indie-review-qbeh-1-the-atlas-cube/

*Review key provided by developer

Recommandé
29.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 juillet 2014
Play time ~29 hours

This game is fantastic. Simple basic mechanics that are easy to learn in order to progress through the game, with then more powers unlocked later on and more obstacle types as well. The puzzles are hard enough to make you think but never too hard to ever stump you. The game may pose to be slightly repetitive after awhile though so I suggest playing with breaks in between. Still worth every penny though. I also love how there are secrets on each level that make you try to discover where they are - some are not trivial and you will just feel great finding them.

The game looks fantastic, has great atmosphere (settings, sound, music, expansiveness), so not only does it test your mind but you also feel immersed in to the game.

Also the game is family friendly - no violence what so ever. I highly recommend this game.
 
Houie

11 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
10.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 juillet 2016
Приветствую. Не дочитывай мой обзор, а бегом покупать игру, к'юрво!
Вот так вот!
А теперь, собственно об игре и пойдет речь.
Головоломка от первого лица, основной задачей в которой является нахождение специальных кубов, с помощью которых можно открывать двери, запускать механизмы, строить выступы по которым можно взбиратся наверх или пригать через пропасти. Дополнительная задача - собирать золотые пирамиды на уровнях.
Все действие происходит в каком-то неведомом мире, где есть только небо, солнце, облака и ты. Уровни очень красивы, несмотря на всю их простоту. Закаты, рассветы, ночь, день, времена года - их сразу узнаешь, как только взглянешь на небо.
Музика хоть и не очень разнообразна, но очень атмосферна и релаксирующая.
Сюжета нет, но его можно додумать. Это своеобразное чистилище. Где есть только небо и ты.
Не надо сравнивать игру с моим любимым порталом - они слишком разные, хоть и жанр один.
Игру я не просто советую покупать, а сильно настаиваю на этом. Ты не пожалеешь!
Атмосфера здесь на таком уровне, что я иногда просто хожу и смотрю на небо, наслаждаясь саундтреком.
Когда я скачал п.и.р.а.т.к.у. и поиграл в нее минут 10, сразу ее удалил и купил игру в стиме.
Это одна из немногих игр, к описанию которой слово шедевр подходит как нельзя лучше.
Минусы лиш два - короткая и нельзя сохранятся когда хочешь.
 
iShi
2
18 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé

Évaluation publiée le 14 octobre 2014

Recommandé
7.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 avril 2015
Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube is a beautiful little atmospheric first person puzzle platformer. A good comparison game would be Q.U.B.E., both Qbeh-1 and Q.U.B.E. feature a very atmospheric world where the story is without narrative and open to interpretation. One of the most notable differences is that, unlike in QUBE which had some color puzzles and other such puzzles, Qbeh-1's puzzle mechanics, although varying, focus around different ways to move your character around a level. In this sense I found the game captured something of older platforming collect-a-thons, the levels themselves get rather large and many times you find yourself scaling a large tower...and add in the secret golden pyramid on each level and it really homes in on that collect-a-thon feel. This game also does a good job in encouraging you to explore, don't expect every piece of the puzzle to be out in the open for you to get your hands on, sometimes you need to look around and check the nooks and crannies to find what you need, something I wish other puzzle platformers did just a bit more.

I really don't think there is much else to say, the gameplay is superb and the aesthetics really set a nice mood (the music is stellar!) I'm glad I bought this when I did and I'm glad I played it. I found the six hours playthrough to be satisfying, and despite having a huge backlog to get through, I am looking forward to continuing by finding the remaining golden pyramids and unlocking the bonus world. Highly recommend to puzzle platformer fans!
 
Big Sugoi ⸢すごい⸥
1,895 produits enregistrés
0
18 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
0.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 mai 2014
Отличная игра, с приятной графикой. Звук надоедает, всего пара мелодий и однообразные звуковые эффекты. Некая инди-приключенческая головоломка. Атмосферная. Управление удобное. Немного наркоманская.
За графику поставлю 8/10 не GTA 5 конечно, звук- 7/10, геймплей- 8/10 немного скучный, управление- 10/10. Игра получает 8.3/10 баллов. Неплохое начало, надеюсь, она будет развиваться.

9.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 décembre 2016
这是一款精致的第一人称解密类动作冒险游戏 没有战斗类要素
游戏中主要采用几种不同类型的方块为素材,带有一定的解密类要素
游戏的场景会随着游戏而不断的变化,一共有6个世界,每个世界都有6个关卡
在解密方面,我们要寻找各种可放置方块,放置到特定的位置,组成一条路,一段阶梯,一把钥匙,一个低重力空间等,以便达到小短腿 破膝盖 主角 就是你 一般达不到的地方
PS.过了之后还要回收方块,这是要逼死强迫症嘛
场景做得十分不错,随便截个屏都能当壁纸,配上时有时无的BGM,玩的时候相当有feel,是玩累了大作,看累了所谓的3A作品后,可以找段比较闲暇的时间,打开这游戏放松休闲 然后低头看一眼被吓尿
还有很重要的一点就是这游戏没有云存档 老子好不容易打到wrold5的存档啊,重装系统后又要从0开始
存档位置C:\Users\Username\AppData\LocalLow\Liquid Flower\Qbeh_1\Profiles
评分:7.3/10 (还老子存档)
PSS.主界面会有卡顿

Non recommandé
15.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 avril 2016
It's hard for me to give it a negative review, I rather give it a mixed review, but given that it's already mostly positive so I decide to reveal its downside.

Every puzzle game has two part: Thinking and execution, the former requires you to find out the solution, the latter requires you to act properly to reach the solution. Basically most puzzle games focus on thinking part, but this game heavily focus on execution, I don't think it should be called a PUZZLE game at all, its thinking part is too easy to be any challenge, while execution part is very tricky and may be frustrating. I seldom take more than 5 seconds to find out the solution, but when executing I get my hand all sweat, it requires you to jump, walking, act, PRECISELY. For example, jump across gaps, there are mass situation you need to jump just before falling to reach other side, or stand on a small cube, try to move 1mm to adjust position and avoid falling. And when you fall, you have to retry again entire section from checkpoint. Dull, tiresome, sometime annoying is my game experience.

I love puzzle games that give me brainstorm experience, enjoy the process of thinking around, I thought this one will provide that kind experience too, unfortunately I'm wrong. I familiar with first-person games so in fact this game doesn't trouble me a lot, I'm just not really into EXECUTION game like this.

But don't misunderstand me, it's not really a bad game. It has unique artwork and beautifully soft music, these two are strong point of this game, many player enjoy this game, but if you are seeking a game make you ponder a lot, think over and over, then this game will not meet your expectation, if you sucks in first-person movement, then you will definitely hate this game.
 
power8888power
388 produits enregistrés
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
24.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 février 2015
"Chi nasce quadrato non può morire tondo"

Anche se non era proprio così, è un po' il mio proverbio, perché per qualche ragione sono sempre inesorabilmente attratto dai puzzle game basati sui cubi, tipo Kairo, o Q.U.B.E., o volendo anche English Country Tune, insomma, avete capito.

Quindi appena ho scoperto l'esistenza di QBeh-1: The Atlas Cube, sapevo che non me lo sarei fatto sfuggire.

Come quelli già citati, infatti, è ambientato in uno strano ed evocativo mondo in rovina fatto quasi esclusivamente di cubi.
Non si sa chi siamo, ma il nostro compito è chiaro: raccogliere dei particolari cubi e utilizzarli per superare i vari ostacoli ed enigmi presenti in ogni livello, per arrivare in fondo.
Livelli che sono ben 30 (+6 segreti) divisi in 5 mondi, ognuno più o meno ♥♥♥ una tematica elementale che ne caratterizza sia l'ambientazione che in parte anche il tipo di enigmi che andremo ad affrontare.
Il problema, se vogliamo, è che molti di questi livelli sono dannatamente lunghi e la prima volta ci si può mettere anche mezz'ora per risolverne uno.

Complice la natura cubosa del mondo di gioco, non è infatti raro sentirsi un po' spaesati di fronte ad enormi aree ♥♥♥ più diramazioni, altrettanti enigmi da risolvere e tortuosi giri dell'oca da fare per poi magari tornare esattamente al punto di partenza, ma ♥♥♥ qualche cubo in più.
Ogni livello è anche disseminato di checkpoint, che però servono solo nella partita in corso, nel caso si muoia cadendo da un precipizio o in qualche altro modo. Se invece si esce dal gioco i progressi temporanei non vengono salvati, e si è costretti a rifare l'intero livello da capo. È una scelta stupida che, specialmente considerando l'ampiezza di alcuni di questi livelli, può rendere il tutto più palloso di quanto dovrebbe.

In tutto vi sono 4 tipi diversi di cubi da poter utilizzare, sbloccabili man mano che si prosegue nei vari mondi e ognuno ♥♥♥ una particolare caratteristica utile per risolvere un certo tipo di enigmi o per raggiungere zone che altrimenti sarebbero state precluse. L'idea è carina e funziona, spesso è necessario combinare più cubi diversi per superare particolari baratri o comunque per superare le prove che il gioco ci para davanti.
L'unico appunto che mi viene da fare è che questi cubi che raccogliamo in giro possono essere posizionati solo in specifici punti, e non ovunque.
Questo limita un po' il giocatore e lo costringe semplicemente a prendere i cubi e a metterli solo dove è previsto che vadano messi. È comunque necessario sfruttare tali punti per costruire scalette o strutture ammassando i cubi per cercare di raggiungere zone impervie, ma non riesco a non pensare che una maggiore libertà avrebbe giovato.

In ogni caso, graficamente è stato fatto un ottimo lavoro, ♥♥♥ effetti di luce, ombre ed elementali resi molto bene che contribuiscono a rendere credibile e realistico il mondo di gioco.
Anche il comparto audio è all'altezza, presentando tracce oniriche, ambientali, rilassanti, ma a volte anche più ritmiche e vivaci.

La longevità è abbastanza elevata e arriverà a superare tranquillamente la decina di ore, che saranno tipo il doppio se ci si mette ad esplorare cubo per cubo ogni livello alla ricerca della piramidina dorata nascosta in luoghi spesso impensabili e difficili da raggiungere, token che saranno necessari per sbloccare il sesto e ultimo mondo.

Se siete come me appassionati di first person puzzler, questo farà al caso vostro. Non è perfetto e alcuni aspetti potevano decisamente essere realizzati in maniera migliore (uno su tutti, i checkpoint), ma se vi lasciate prendere e non vi fate scoraggiare dalla lunghezza di molti livelli, vi piacerà.
 
Lucathegreat
971 produits enregistrés
0
8 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 juin 2016
Absolutely spellbinding, and the music soundtrack is so relaxing. There are no monster chases, nothing to kill, no time clock to beat -- it's just you and some great puzzles... The small worlds actually make it feel a bit like an exploration game.

Another bonus is that a Level Editor was added so you can also create your own Qbeh-1 Worlds.

SIDE NOTE: I've heard the game plays well in VR systems -- I'm not sure whether I would have the nerve to try it (some of those leaps in the game are pretty intimidating)... but I can imagine how breathtaking it must look in 3D.

Recommandé
52.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 février 2016
La Cruceta Inquieta, mentor de Steam

Si algo bueno, más allá de su propia existencia, ha tenido Portal, es la senda que dejó marcada para que otros, siguiendo un esquema parecido, dieran rienda suelta a su imaginación para la creación de mundos y aventuras basadas en la resolución de puzles integrados en el entorno. "Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube" bebe de dicho esquema para crear una experiencia totalmente diferente a la que ofrece la saga de Valve, pero que posee determinados elementos en común ♥♥♥ ella y que la convierten en un todo disfrutable de principio a fin, ya únicamente ♥♥♥ su base de rompecabezas interactivos.

En este caso la trama no juega un papel tan importante como en otros referentes del género, pero es el silencio y la soledad el hilo conductor que nos guiará entre puzle y puzle. La sensación de soledad es absoluta y se incrementa aún más por el hecho de que toda la arquitectura sobre la que se desarrolla la acción está en ruinas y, además, levita sobre un cielo bajo el que no se atisba tierra alguna.

La historia, aunque aparentemente inexistente, parece que nos sea narrada a través del nombre ♥♥♥ que cada nivel ha sido bautizado, creando cierta idea de progresión desde el inicio hasta nuestro objetivo final: el Cubo Atlas. No obstante, este aspecto no supondrá nuestra mayor preocupación, sino el hecho de continuar avanzando en los puzles para, en cada nivel, alcanzar la puerta final que nos llevará hasta el siguiente. Simple pero igualmente entretenido porque se concentra toda la intensidad en la jugabilidad.

Los gráficos, pese a no ser los mejores, son completamente suficientes para tratarse de un videojuego indie y para el ambiente que trata de crear. Modelados, texturas, efectos y el propio diseño artístico hacen que de verdad nos sintamos aislados en el interior de construcciones y estructuras antiguas, inexploradas y misteriosas, no siempre pudiendo ser calificadas de inhóspitas por la inclusión de elementos naturales como la vegetación y la hojarasca, la iluminación natural y el propio cielo en todas sus variantes de color, que crean espacios más cálidos y luminosos.

En cuanto a la música, podemos encontrar composiciones de todo tipo (algunas terminan haciéndose un tanto pesadas, todo hay que decirlo) pero siempre ♥♥♥ un denominador común: enfatizar la soledad de los extraños espacios que hemos de atravesar. Da la sensación, aunque no sea del todo cierta, de que la música acompaña a los rompecabezas, definiendo casi un ritmo de resolución de los mismos o, incluso en algunos casos, aumentando nuestro nivel de frustración frente a ellos por su repetitividad. ♥♥♥ esto se quiere aclarar que, pese a ser un conjunto de melodías aparentemente de acompañamiento, la música termina siendo un factor psicológico de influencia constante en la búsqueda de soluciones y en el avance de la aventura. Aunque en ningún caso la dificultad es frustrante ni nos obligue a ello, siempre tenemos la oportunidad de bajar el volumen cuando algún puzle se nos "atragante".

En el aspecto "jugable", el control en primera persona responde bien excepto quizá a la hora de saltar, puesto que, en las secciones de plataformas, el hecho de que la acción del salto esté tan limitada nos obliga a calcular algo más nuestros movimientos o tener que pasar por el proceso de "prueba y error" por creer que podíamos llegar a determinada superficie que parecía posible alcanzar pero que en realidad estaba fuera de nuestro alcance. Aun así, el diseño de niveles ha sido concienzudamente elaborado para permitir la utilización de los cubos ♥♥♥ los que resolveremos los rompecabezas, dándonos también la oportunidad de usarlos para llegar a zonas premeditadamente ocultas y donde encontrar elementos coleccionables o secretos, e incluso (♥♥♥ ayuda tal vez de ciertos pequeños fallos de diseño) alcanzar zonas "prohibidas" de los escenarios ♥♥♥ las que se añade un componente de exploración que puede alargar la experiencia de juego (cosa que también se logra ♥♥♥ la, relativamente reciente, inclusión del editor de niveles).

Son los cubos el elemento base en la resolución de los puzles, habiéndolos de distinto color y, por ello, efecto y utilidad a lo largo de la aventura. No se ha hecho hincapié en este aspecto a lo largo de la aventura para no arruinar el elemento principal del videojuego frente a la aparente ausencia de trama, pero sí puede decirse que su uso crea situaciones muy originales y permite la búsqueda de soluciones dispares por la libertad en la combinación de los mismos, haciendo que, pese a algún que otro "bug" o problema de colisiones, la resolución de los puzles sea en cada momento gratificante y clara, pero no evidente.

Concluyendo, "Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube" puede que, también por su condición de indie, no llegue a los niveles de inmersión y excelencia de los referentes del género de aventura/puzle/rompecabezas, pero consigue crear una ambientación atractiva y ♥♥♥ una personalidad propia, y hacer de la resolución de puzles el único motivo de avance, cosa que, por otra parte, es en realidad el objetivo primero de cualquier juego frente a complejas tramas u otros elementos que en la actualidad los acercan más al cine que a su faceta como creación interactiva.
 
G. S.

Évaluation publiée le 18 octobre 2014
Qbeh is another puzzle platformer that is remarkably similar to Q.U.B.E. Both have the same cuboid environment, and both are FPS puzzle games that feel a little unfinished at the time of their release. Qbeh should have some sort of story, at least a symbolic abstract one, to accompany the gameplay. At the moment we don't even know if the player is human or not since there are no viewmodels. For reasons I don't fully understand, this game has hooked me in a way that most of the stuff I have bought recently has failed to do so and I recommend it for all fans of portal or Q.U.B.E. You will not be dissapointed (as long as you don't alt tab).

0.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 janvier 2019
Qbeh-1 is a game designed by people who think that grinding is the pinnacle of gaming. "Here's a level that requires no thinking!" "Here's a level that requires no thinking and making a tricky jump!" "Here's a level that requires no thinking, collecting a bunch of cubes, and then making a tricky jump!"

When the two most attained achievements are "fall into the abyss" and "rage quit', it's not a fiendishly difficult game, it's just a bad game. Prospective players who are interested in sovling physical puzzles by placing cubes should turn to Q.U.B.E., which is far from perfect but miles better than Qbeh-1.

Recommandé
15.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 aout 2015
10/10, one of my favorite games

Qbeh-1 is amzing. The developers sucessfully created an amazingly original premise for this puzzle game. You are provided with a total of 36 beautiful levels. If you find yourself hungry for more by the end, you can browse the workshop and download community made levels. There are 6 unique worlds with different atmospheres and coloring styles.

You progress through each level by using the cubes scattered across the map. There are quite a few different types of cubes, each providing a specific function; anti-gravity, power, transportation, basic, etc.

What really sells this game on me though is the beauty of each level. To be concise, the maps look like minecraft with shaders, without any lag.

I definately recommend this game, although be sure to watch the videos and take a look at the screenshots to see for yourself.

The ending on 5-6 is amazing
 
Dominus Aventiūs

0
Non recommandé
5.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 mai 2016
I'm only two worlds into the game but, well, there's already a laundry list of problems.

First off, the game is barely a puzzle game. It tries to act like one, but a lot of the game is jumping, and a lot of the jumps are kind of terrifying, since you can barely make them, and a good number of them are over death pits where falling means back to the last checkpoint.

That's the thing, what's up with the checkpointing? Why are there so few per level, why are they so far apart? It really makes no sense. You end up having to redo a lot of stuff if you die between checkpoints, and it's just... really tedious. Really unfun.

The game also seems to want to make you explore to find secrets, but also punishes you for exploring by killing you a lot if you try to explore? It doesn't work out.

The puzzle design itself feels really clunky; I'm rarely sure whether or not what I did was the intended solution or not because it feels so janky and off. Sometimes I feel like I'm breaking a puzzle and I actually am, other times I do a similar type of puzzle-breaking that turns out to be the right solution? It's so confusing.

The game also has a major oversight where it tries to make you lose cubes by having indentations where you have to put a cube in, but a lot of the time you can stand on the ledge above it, go just far enough out, and grab the cube from inside the indentation, thus generally giving you an extra cube to work with. And I doubt this was intended, but, hey, it works.

There was one puzzle where the solution was literally just a hidden passage that let you skip a door that would otherwise require a blue key block to open. So that's... something.

Also, there's fall damage for some arbitrary reason. Another one of those anti-exploring things as it's never been relevant in a puzzle yet.

The basic mechanic of this game, even, is just... kind of dumb. There's an arbitrary limit on how far away you can grab stuff, where it's too far to be "realistic" but too close to be "useful". It feels like an arbitrary limitation that only exists to make puzzles more tedious.

Another arbitrary mechanic. It's really picky about where you can put blocks. You can't stack blocks down, at all, unless you have a deep enough angle under the blocks. Not just "a bit below" but "standing under". So sometimes you'll end up needing to stop what you're doing, go back down and put a block under another block, then come back up to continue onward, because of this completely pointless limitation.

You also can't place blocks in a bridge in front of you, so yep, go back down, walk to the other side, stretch the bridge out... doesn't this sound tedious as heck? Believe me, it is.

And even then... the game runs out of interesting things to do with its basic block building mechanic about one world in. Yet still continues to reuse the same slow building puzzles over and over, for... some reason or other, I really don't know.

This is just two worlds' worth of experience and I highly doubt it's going to get better but I'm inevitably going to end up playing more so I'll update this later... I just, already had a lot I wanted to say and definitely wouldn't recommend this game based off what I've played. There's starting out on the wrong foot, and then there's not having a right foot to start with, period, and this game... seems to be the latter.

World 3 update: The game introduces a low-gravity hi jump mechanic... that's horribly inconsistent and I can't figure out why jump height varies so much. Getting stuck on ledges also becomes a thing. The rest of the game is pretty much the same tedious schlock. I'm not sure I can keep playing much further, honestly, this game is just a special kind of unpleasant.
 
rory
910 produits enregistrés
0

Recommandé
62.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 novembre 2017
Logická hra, ve které se člověk ponoří do několika jiných světů tvořené kostičkami. Hra obsahuje 6 světů, každý svět tvoří 6 levelů. Hra spočívá v procházce v daném prostředí a dostat se za pomocí různých kostek do cíle. Kostky, které lze ve hře vzít jsou barevně odlišeny a každá má specifické vlastnosti. Tato hra slouží spíše pro relaxaci, i když občas narazíte na místa, kdy je potřeba pohyb řádně načasovat, popř. jednat rychle.
Q-beh kromě zajímavého prostředí také dokresluje poměrně specifická hudba, která v některých levelech působí velmi pozitivně, v některých trochu chmurně. Ale na každého může působit skutečně jinak, jedná se o subjektivní pocit. V některých levelech si lze všimnout při zkoumání prostředí také zvuků dotvářejících prostředí např. ševelení listů na stromech, bzučení včel nebo tekoucí vody...
I když se jedná o relaxační hru, lze v ní bohužel umřít. Nejčastějším způsobem je spadnutí dolů z platformy s docela nepříjemným zvukem, přimáčknutím dveří, popř. dotykem určitých míst... Naštěstí to neznamená, že musíte začínat level úplně od začátku. V každém prostředí jsou umístěny speciální sochy, ke kterým když se dostanete a projdete okolo nich, tak se hra uloží a v případě smrti se objevíte u poslední sochy, u které k uložení došlo.
Hra je navíc zpestřená hledáním žlutých točících se jehlanů, ke kterým není vždy úplně snadné se dostat a ne vždy jsou viditelné na první pohled a mohou být pro hráče určitou výzvou. Za vysbírání všech jehlanů v jednom světě jsou hráči odměněni achievementem. :-)
Do hry byla přidán i speciální mód, ve kterém si hráči dami mohou vyzkoušet vytvořit prostředí z kostiček a zkusit si jej projít. Což považuji za velmi kladné a přínosné.
Hra je spíše určena pro trpělivé hráče a pro hráče, kteří si rádi trochu potrápí mozek. Hru naopak nedoporučuji hráčům, kteří trpí závratěmi (leda, že by si sami přáli je postupně překonávat, tato hra je pro tento účel skvělá příležitost). Hra nabízí občas pohled z veliké výšky a občas se pohybujete v těchto výškách skutečně jen na vlastních položených kostičkách či lítáte ve vzduchu.

+ pěkné originální prostředí
+ zvuky dokreslující prostředí
+ hudba
+ podpora myšlení zábavnou formou
+ možnost hledání skrytého jehlanu
+ achivementy a sběratelské kartičky
+ rozmanitost funkčností kostiček

- hra mi někdy trochu bugovala, ale zase ne tak často (např. jsem skočila a přes kostičku jsem propadla zpět na zem)
- občasné leknutí při rozpadání kostiček (naštěstí se rozpadají pomalu, takže hráč má možnost se zachránit)

Hra se mi celkově líbí. Pustím si ji vždy, když potřebuji relaxovat, o něčem přemýšlet či na chvilku uniknout a ponořit se do jiného světa a odstranit tím nahromaděný stres ze skutečného, ne vždy přívětivého, života.
 
Šťastná maminka EmotiveDahlia
0

41.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 juin 2017
Vidéo YouTube™: What is Qbeh 1 The Atlas Cube? 
Vues : 33
This video seeks to answer one question what is Qbeth-1 The Atlas Cube? In the style of WTF is... and This is..., and like those videos I to go over the premise of the game.


Boy how do I describe Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube? I guess the best place to start is with the objective of the game. Your overall objective is to find cubes throughout the level which are needed to not only traverse the levels , but also to complete puzzles in each of the levels. There are 6 worlds each with 6 levels in them for a total of 36 levels. In each level there are only certain places you can put the cubes marked by golden squares on the floors, walls, and chillings in each level. Now some of the cubes are hidden while others are in the open. Also the cubes themselves come in variety of colors such as red, blue, purple, green, and occasionally white. Each cube having a unique property except the red cubes. The blue cubes open doors, the purple ones have a gravity less field around them when place them, and finally the white cubes are used to activate portals. Now you use a combination of these cubes to traverse the world and solve puzzles. There is a secondary objective to find the golden pyramid hidden in each level. The pyramids themselves don't do anything, but you will need to find them if you want to complete the game. Next is the Story.

There is no story. No I am serious. I have looked everywhere and I can't find anything about any kind of story in the game or on the internet. This isn't like a Soulsborne game either where you have to piece the story together. There just isn't one. Which is said since I really enjoyed the many of the aspects of the game such as the soundtrack and atmosphere of the game, but I'll take no story in place of half backed one any day of the week. With the being said this game isn't going long for you to complete it, and while I enjoyed the puzzles. Trying to find the golden pyramid pieces gave me an extra incentive to keep playing the game. With that being said not matter what you choose to do this game isn't particularly long. I complete the game can be completed in 40 hrs, and beat in 20 hrs. Overall I did enjoy my time with this game, but don't be looking for a deep or hard game. I would recommend it to anyone who likes puzzles games that aren't to challenging or looking for a nice game to chill out with
 
ShadowTemplar59
2

Recommandé
15.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 aout 2016
Qbeh is a first person puzzle game where the player must progress through a series of temple style structures that are built out of cubes, and are floating amongst the clouds. I really enjoyed playing Qbeh. Its a shame that it didn't get a lot of media attention, and consequently I guess not many people have played it, because I think its much better than certain other games that gained a lot more hype *cough*thewitness*cough*.

The main objective of each level is simply to enter the portal to travel to the next level. The problem is, each level is filled with ledges that are too high to climb, and gaps in the floor that are too long to jump across. Fortunately, scattered around each level are coloured blocks that you can collect and place in specific locations to help you reach your goal. Each type of block is useful in different ways. Red blocks just exist to stand on, blues can unlock doors and power moving platforms, purples create a field of low gravity and greens can move either horizontally or vertically but disappear after a few seconds.

The level design is really intelligent, especially later in the game, when you're using multiple different blocks together, and you encounter additional hazards, such as fans that can push you off a ledge, and a black ooze covering the walls and floor that kills you instantly if you touch it. Many areas feel like they've got multiple solutions. Every level also has a glowing prism hidden away in a secret location. Finding these usually requires thorough exploration, and creative block usage. But they also give you that really satisfying "I am the smartest person in the world" feeling.

I've finished all the main levels and found half the secrets, in just under 9 hours. There are a few more bonus levels but they're unlocked by finding all the secrets, which is something that only the most dedicated players will do. I didn't encounter any bugs or crashes and the controls are fully rebindable. I also have to say the music is great, and it creates a relaxing, chilled out mood.

The only real negative I can mention is the lack of a story tying all the levels together. It kind of feels like we're exploring the ruins of a dead civilisation, so it would have been cool to know more.

If you enjoy first person puzzle games such as Portal, Talos Principle or Qube, I highly recommend Qbeh. I'd say its worth a full price purchase, but at least give it a try on a sale.
 
G00N3R
516 produits enregistrés

30.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 janvier 2017
I found it to be fun overall, but a little monotonous at times. Most puzzles have multiple ways of doing them, so it's sort of up to your imagination and creativity, which I like.

The difficulty scales fairly well and never gets too hard.

My biggest complaint about this game is not being able to save where you want because the save spots are horrible for the most part. Also, there are puzzles that you don't know what to do until you get there and then you have to start over, etc until you get to the end.... mainly one in particular in the last cube world. Trial and error should not be part of a puzzle. Granted, some would argue that you could do it first time, but you have to be quick and accurate that first time through.

Anyway, it's no award winning game, but is worth it on sale.
 
DeathWish808

Évaluation publiée le 5 janvier 2016
Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube is a minimalistic first person puzzle game. There's not really a story per say, but you ultimately progress to power up the Atlas which I think creates more worlds. I'm always a sucker for first person puzzle games and even though there are a lot better games out there, this one is still pretty satisfying. I would say the majority of puzzles are moderate difficulty, but finding all the tokens is extremely difficult. There isn't a whole lot of handholding in this one either so you pretty much have to figure it out as you go.

They've also added a level editor since I've played it so that's a bonus.

After two years later updated my review...
I love your game very much,and it was the second game I bought in my steam account with original price several years ago.These years I have played throught the main part of game for more than ten times and every time was able to bring me new discoveries! Évaluation publiée le 26 novembre 2016
Esse jogo é muito bom, vale cada centavo... Além de puzzles incríveis que vão ficando cada vez mais complicados (meio que você tá jogando, não consegue resolver aquele puzzle e para de jogar. Mas aí uma você acaba começando a pensar naquilo mesmo sem estar jogando, e... *mind blow*, vê que não é tão complicado assim) a arte dele é sensacional, sempre que jogo tiro 200 prints, é muito lindo mesmo ; e ainda tem a Soundtrack, que *encaixa perfeitamente* com a atmosfera dele. Nesse jogo você está sozinho, sempre... (será mesmo?) em plataformas no céu. Tem manhã, tarde, fim de tarde, noite... É muito lindo. E o gameplay? Sensacional! Não é que nem Minecraft que você vai botando os bloco por aí não! Tem várias fases, vários puzzles e vários jeitos de resolvê-los (as vezes) ; além de ainda ter secrets!

~~

É sério, esse jogo é muito bom, vale cada centavo! (e ainda fica baratinho na promoção (: ).
É uma experiência imperdível, compre, não irá se arrepender!

Recommandé
28.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 juillet 2016
ファーストパーソンアクションパズルゲーム。
ブロックで構築されたレベルを探索し特殊なブロックを見つけて、そのブロックを上手く使いながらゴールを目指すゲームだ。特殊ブロックは、足場に使えるだけのもの、鍵として使えるもの、低重力フィールドを展開するもの、それ自体が移動するものがあり、特定の設置個所に設置してブロック同士を連結して使うことができる。他のゲームで例えるなら"Minecraft"のアクションにパズル要素を合わせたようなものとなっている。

[ゲーム性]
探索、アクション、パズルという3つの要素が組み合わさったゲームであるがどちらかと言えば探索重視だ。なぜなら、探索しないことにはブロックとブロックの設置場所を見つけないことには何も始まらないからだ。必要なブロックさえ手に入れていれば設置場所が限られているために、パズルの解き方もだいたい決まってくる。
また、アクション性は意外に高い。World5から登場するForce Cube(上に乗って移動できるブロック)が少し曲者で挙動を理解するまで、何度か落下死を繰り返してしまうかもしれない。操作キャラ自体のジャンプ力が低いことと初見殺し的な場面もあり、死んで覚えることが必要だ。場合よってはレベルリスタートを余儀なくされる詰みもある。しかし、一度クリアしてそのレベルを覚えてしまえば再プレイではすんなりクリアできると思う。

[シークレット]
各レベルにはTokenというシークレットが隠されている。Tokenに近づくとキーンという音が聞こえるが見つけるのは難しい。とんでもないところに隠されているものが多い。

[エディタ]
このゲームにはプレイヤーがオリジナルマップを作成してワークショップにUPできるエディタが付いている。しかし、現状(Ver. 1.2.1)のエディタの機能はなんとかマップを作成できるという程度のものでしかない。UNDO/REDOすらない編集機能の少なさだ。また、エディタ再起動の度に光源位置がリセットされるなどBugも多い。しかし、エディタが貧弱に関わらずワークショップにはオリジナルを超えるような素晴らしいユーザーレベルがあるのでぜひプレイするといいだろう。

ゲームのつくりにやや雑さがありレベルデザインについてもイジワルなところがあるが、一見すると行けないようなところも手持ちのブロックで試行錯誤して行けるようにしていく過程は面白い。壮大さを感じるマップのつくりと雰囲気も良い。死んで覚えるゲーム性を許容でき、ボクセルゲームの探索とアクションが好きなら良いゲームだと思う。
 
elltar
3,721 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé

Recommandé
7.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 novembre 2019
하늘 사원 ( 수호병들아, 이 필멸자들이 접근하지 못하게 막아라! )

플레이 시간 : 7.6시간
가성비 : 보통
몰입도 : 다소 높음.
난이도 : 낮음~보통

하늘 위에 떠 있는 네모네모 사원에서 퍼즐을 풀어야 한다. 분위기는 다르지만 천공의 성 라퓨타가 떠오르긴 했다. 주로 빨간 큐브는 발판으로 삼고, 파란 큐브는 작동장치, 보라큐브는 저중력 장치, 초록색은 부유장치 쯤으로 보면 된다. 게임의 분위기는 챕터에 따라서 조금씩 바뀐다. ost도 분위기에 잘 어울린다. 아무래도 하늘에 떠 있다보니 낙사 위험이 있어서 긴장이 많이 된다. 손에서 땀이 좀 흐르는 편. 난이도는 어렵지 않고 혼자서 충분히 풀만 하다. 조작감도 나쁘지 않다. 특히 점프키가 아주 잘 든다.

후반에 파란 큐브가 널판지 마냥 길게 늘어나는 버그가 하나 있었지만 그 외에는 깔끔하게 잘 만들었다. 아주 재밌는 정도는 아니지만 퍼즐게임을 좋아하는 사람에게 추천할만 하다. 힐링도 좀 된다. 다만 너무 밋밋하고 비슷한 퍼즐에 신선함이 좀 부족하다.

히오스나 할 걸.
 
꼬마용
341 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
34.7 h en tout

astral_cyborg

Évaluation publiée le 13 janvier 2015
Q.U.B.EやPortal等が好きな人にお勧めです。
面白さの度合いPortal＞＞＞Qbeh-1≧Q.U.B.E

キューブを如何にして使うかで進路が開けます。
キューブの設置には決まりはなくどんな方法でもいいので先に進めばよい。
後半の壁登りや空中移動のステージがかなり悩んだので、いい頭の体操になるよ＾＾
隠しアイテムのtoken探しもあるのでやりこみ度は高いと思います。

以下ネタバレ
実績の一つ、高難易度と思われるWothy(Reach atlas without dying)は、（途中何度落下やミスがあってもよい）world６までクリアしたらメイン画面のプロフィール欄にて新たにプロフィールを作成しactiveにしたら解除できました。バグだと思います。

Dry Feet は水たまりにだけ足が着かなければOK。world1～5クリアで解除できますｂ

This is a great concept, and could be a great game. However, I was frustrated by the slow movement speed and the game's reliance on well-timed jumps. Évaluation publiée le 6 juillet 2015
1.
Сюжет: Сюжета нет. Просто решаешь "головоломки" и идёшь из "комнаты" в "комнату". Достаточно уныло и скучно. Головоломки (если это вообще можно ими назвать) очень быстро надоедают. [3/10]

2.
Графика: Действительно красиво. [10/10]

3.
Геймплей: Мышь + клавиатура. По какой-то необъяснимой причине настройки по умолчанию не хотели работать, пришлось переставить. Сильно раздражает тот факт, что твоё невидимое тело каким-то образом стоя на противоположном краю кубика мешает поставить в другой стороне второй кубик. [6/10]

4.
Музыка и звуки: Рассляюляющая музыка, звуки к месту. [10/10]

5.
Оптимизация: Всё замечательно. [10/10]

Итог:
7,5 парящих кубов из 10.
