2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
11.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 novembre 2020
I heard of this game when seeing a review of Neon Junctions. Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube is an imaginative, substantial puzzle-platformer with a fair amount of varied game mechanics. Like Neon Junctions, you collect and place cubes, but in this you use them to build bridges, create obstructions or ledges, or to activate switches. Some are simple building blocks, some special ones have supernatural powers like anti-gravity, or the ability to move and carry you across things. It's a very enjoyable, quite tricky game, with precise jumping and often a keen sense of timing required. There are checkpoints scattered across each level so you rarely have to replay a huge swathe of each one if you fall, but I did have a problem sometimes with quite alarming twitchiness of the field of view occurring in some of the middle levels. Thankfully this didn't last long and didn't interfere with some of the more tricky and delicate sections. Also, like me, you may have to change your V-sync setting in the last chapter, as apparently there's a bug that makes it impossible otherwise (more precisely, the green cubes wouldn't travel quickly enough). I got this advice from Steam and it worked immediately.

The Atlas Cube is a really nice indie platformer and well worth a look. You may need to put aside any fear of heights though...
 
Steve Back

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
9.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 avril 2016
I'm reminded of that lesson from the YouTube series Extra Credits - Mechanics are more important than content. You may have some good ideas, and this game certainly does (enough to at least recommend it), but it's spread so thin that a lot of it becomes tedious, especially around the middle. Still, it has a pleasant aesthetic and smooth frame rate, the gameplay is functional enough that the first-person platforming doesn't become too frustrating, and the mechanics are interesting even if they outstay their welcome sometimes.

IMPORTANT: Turn vsync on. The puzzles involving the green cubes are impossible with it turned off. You'll see.
 
Reg of Dorkness

292.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 juin 2016
The negative review that came up first for me on this page is so misguided that I feel obligated to counter with a review of my own, which will be my first ever. First of all, there are no broken or unintended mechanics involved with grabbing cubes at weird angles, that's all part of the game. In fact, the game is remarkably free of such things. With hundreds of hours of game time, the only glitches I’m aware of all involve a specific series of steps that has to be taken to enable the glitch, none of which have ever happened to me accidentally during gameplay. The game is stable, extremely well thought-out, and the only complaint that rings remotely true is the one about the checkpoint/save system, which is indeed sometimes frustrating, but not nearly as much as what I’ve encountered in other games - this is a minor nuisance we’re talking about, not a deal-breaker.

Qbeh-1 is one of my all-time favorite games, continually teasing you onward with gorgeous vistas and mysterious ruins and strange enigmatic machines... It‘s a pleasing blend of puzzle-solving and exploration, that introduces new gameplay elements at a perfect pace. There are new kinds of cubes to be found in each of 5 worlds, each containing many levels, and then, when you think you’ve finally mastered the game and reached the end, you’re given a highly motivating reason to go back and do it all over again, this time with an emphasis more on exploration. And when the final world’s final secret is unlocked and the game truly completed, there are now many new Workshop community levels that can be played, greatly enhancing re-playability.

I admit I do like FP puzzle games quite a bit, but that doesn’t quite explain why I love this game so much. It’s really a hard question to answer, but I think it comes down to two things that make Qbeh-1 a standout even amongst similar games: immersive-ness and aesthetics. The first is a bit inexplicable, since the game has no real story to speak of, nonetheless you are totally THERE, completely immersed, in the moment, eager to explore the world and get to the next magnificent vista... Which brings us to the second thing, the aesthetics: the visuals are just spectacular. I can’t think of another game in which I spent so much time just staring at the sheer beauty of my surroundings. I found myself constantly stopping to take screenshots, in the manner of a tourist in an exotic land who stops to take photos - I couldn’t help myself. There’s such a strong sense of atmosphere to many of the locations, such ethereal beauty, enhanced by a haunting, often plaintive soundtrack that creates a perfect musical ambience that’s barely noticed because it fits in so well, but which will haunt you once it’s gone.

The game gets all this stuff right, in fact I have referred to it as a playable work of art, which it unquestionably is. If that doesn’t sound appealing to you, then maybe the game isn’t meant for you. But for those who live their lives always needing to find out what’s at the end of that lonely path through the wilderness, who can’t help but explore an ancient ruin, this is for you. I’m guessing this is as close as a game can get to pure poetry, and I’m actually not one for poetry, usually. If you like the awesome, the mysterious, the unknown, try this. It’s not expensive at all, and you may be surprised at how much you will like it and return to it. And don’t get me wrong, the puzzle aspect is strong, there are some real challenges here for those who just like puzzles.

I really can’t say enough about this game, it’s a genuine hidden gem. At the price, I can almost guarantee you’ll find it money well spent, and if it‘s on sale, why the heck wouldn’t you? Highly recommended, for those who are in the intended audience for this kind of thing, and even for those who aren't. Check it out.
 
almechist

Évaluation publiée le 16 février 2019
Qbeh is a quite minimalistic puzzle platformer which requires mainly spatial thinking and planning with very limited resources.

While it is greatly designed, it lacks any story whatsoever and looks shoddy at best. Just mechanically speaking, I can definitely recommend this, but there are a lot other puzzle games with actual story and a lot more immersion to be had.

Even considering the not too high asking price I still would only get this above 50% discount and then only if you've run out of other puzzle games.

Recommandé
103.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 juin 2014
Surreal and engaging from the start, this is definitely my kind of game when I want something challenging; yet won't take me all day to progress. Qbeh-1 is certainly a puzzle game, but you are certainly not forced into a linear approach. There are often multiple approaches to resolve challenges. You can utilize hidden paths, strategic jumps, and a variety of cubes with different functions to tackle each task. And, particularly later in the game, you can be tempted into making decisions that could force you into a trap. But it's all part of the fun to learn what to do and what to avoid! The tougher challenges bring greater satisfaction when you eventually solve them.
There are also secret tokens each level to find, although they are optional. Since I enjoy these secrets, I find that these extras force me to take each world with a holistic approach (figure out where a secret might be by considering the whole map), as well as an analytical one.
The visuals, sounds, and music bring a fresh and even soothing atmosphere to the game. Yet there is also danger: Looking below you and seeing nothing but sky can tease more than a little vertigo. You must always watch your step! The controls are very simple and avoid complexity that can interfere with immersion into the game. And you build upon your acquired knowledge as you go. You learn solutions to common puzzles, and sometimes you gain inspiration to improve those solutions. And you truly feel you're learning when you are able to combine those solutions into an even greater one.
I truly recommend this game to anyone. Even if puzzle games aren't normally your cup of tea, the relaxed pace, beautiful setting, and multiple approaches may just attract both the hardcore and casual gamers alike.
 
truthseer27

Non recommandé
2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 octobre 2017
I really want to like this game, but I just can't.

Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube (Electric Boogaloo) looks like a game of the walking-sim puzzle-block variety, but looks are deceiving. The puzzles here aren't really puzzles at all, only mild inconveniences. The only reason the game is challenging is you're trying not to fall off of tiny ledges as you jump around with a modest interface.

I'll give you a concrete example. One of the levels gives you seventeen cubes, but you can beat everything in the level with only ten cubes. The "puzzles" are using cubes to make ledges in obvious places, but whoever made the game was not a puzzle person at all. They included way too many cubes because they weren't able to do the puzzles themselves, and the puzzles are neither inventive nor interesting as a result. The only "challenge" is to find a slightly-harder-to-reach game element in every level.

I like hard puzzles and I was very disappointed, because the game had so much potential! The game music is airy and pleasant, the visuals are pretty, and the controls are relatively smooth. But the puzzles simply aren't puzzles, there aren't any true challenges, and "try not to fall" becomes repetitive almost immediately. This could have been a great game with each level introducing new ideas and tricks to doing things with fewer cubes, but they should have employed at least one puzzle person in its design, because the design sucks. The game is very boring, and I can't recommend it.

Maybe if they do a sequel they'll put some effort into the game design next time. One can hope!
 
Trick Question

Definitely a fun game to play over and over and over ... and then build so you can play some more!

13.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 aout 2014
QBEH-1: The Atlas Cube is a first person puzzle platformer that takes you on a quest through a variety of divergent worlds, each filled with new mysteries and secrets to uncover.
The basics behind the game are simple, tasking players with collecting cubes that can be used to build steps and platforms to reach a portal to the next level. There are a limited number of cubes in each level, and they can only be placed upon glowing segments of wall and floor tiles, making Qbeh-1 a challenging game that requires the player to think about their next steps and anticipate the eventual consequences.
The music is soothing and pleasant.
The graphics looks good so far, with vast blocky levels that stretch to the horizon, inventive level design and some great texture work that makes it easy to spot interactive elements and collectable objects.
Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube is an interesting little block puzzle game which you should try out if you like first person puzzle games.

Sounds 8/10
Graphics 6/10
Gameplay 7/10
Atmosphere 8/10

If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:
http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guides
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curation

Also feel free to check out my YouTube Channel:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
4.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 février 2015
QBeh-1 is an atmospheric 1st person puzzle based on simplicity and elegant looks: it’s a relaxing experience that it should be taken note by everyone who enjoyed games like Portal, Antichamber or Q.U.B.E. It is very similar with those mentioned titles but it maintains its own personality too.

Mainly, it is an exploration game that is taking place in four distinct worlds, all of them created by cubes. Each world contains six stages: you have to navigate into tricky mazes and thus finding the final door that leads to the next stage. The primary game mechanic has to do with obtaining and managing the special cubes that lay sparsely on the map. There 3 or 4 types of different colored cubes : the most common type is the orange one, which is used like footstool for creating platforms and steps that help you move into other areas. The blue one serves like a switch and is used for opening doors or operating elevators and there is a purple one that alters gravity in the surrounding area.

Each stage contains a hidden rotating pyramid that waits patiently for you. In order to locate it you have to use your wits and find alternative routes that will often send you in seemingly inaccessible locations on the map. What is it for you if you find all the pyramids you ask? Well, nothing really except for the sheer joy of doing it!

QBeh-1 excels in gameplay but it also looks surprisingly pleasing to the eye: the graphics are lacking in detail but they have a unique art design inspired loosely by Minecraft. Combined with the excellent ambient soundtrack, they create a very soothing, relaxing experience that you will definitely keep you occupied for a long time.

In a nutshell, I highly recommend QBeh-1 to everyone who looks for a good and challenging puzzle game.
 
dyolf

31.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 janvier 2015
This game is pleasant to look at and enjoyable to play. It gets the difficultly right without being confronting. The levels are cleverly designed with the game set high in the sky. You rarely get led up the garden path and if you do its for a good reason. While players aren't provided much guidance, intuition should kick in. For example, I just knew there had to be hidden secrets. The lack of attaining a corresponding achievement after completing the first world confirmed my suspicions.

The art direction is understated. Ambient music only plays on the occasion. The lighting is effective and varies for each level. The sporadic plant-life spruces up the spartan levels nicely while the background clouds are gorgeous. Its easy to recommended this game. 7.5/10

Recommandé
21.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 novembre 2017
Pros:
  • Peaceful and relaxing, à la TRI...except, thanks to the outstanding ambient/experimental music and amazing skies, this one feels dreamier (quite literally head-in-clouds dreamy).
  • It's casual enough to allow multiple solutions, and even if you're not accustomed to puzzle games, it's still worth it, for then the game would feel like a solid puzzle game.
  • Invites exploration, and thanks to the level editor, creativity.
♥♥♥♥:
  • Slightly buggy (the trees had a weird sprite for me), but gameplay is largely unaffected. The worst there's been is a misplaced cube, but it's not at all like the game's gonna crash.
  • There's one secret thing (token) per level. Unlike in TRI, where you could always backtrack to get a secret, in Qbeh-1 that's not always possible.
  • The savepointing system, while immersive, can be selective. However the real issue is that it's impossible to save more than once at the same savepoint.
Recommended with an 8/10. Well worth the price. Estimated playtime: 6-8 hours (13-15 hours for the 100%er)
 
The Sojourner

Évaluation publiée le 3 décembre 2016
I haven't finished the game yet (2 worlds left), but I am fully confident that I can create a verdict

Pros:
__________________________________

- Visually it's a very nice game

- beautiful soundtrack, great soundwork

- levels aren't too short or long

- quite relaxing


♥♥♥♥:
________________________________

- my biggest gripe was that if you are a completionist, you spend most time wondering about in attempts to locate a spinning prism hidden in every level, and there are levels that have points of no return, so you have to replay the level if you missed it; it would be best if you could traverse levels freely without having to worry about being locked out of some area, because otherwise it is a very relaxing game

- sometimes the level design isn't clear and you don't know what to do


________________________________

If you are looking for mild puzzles, relaxing gamesplay, and nice music, I can only recommend this.

Évaluation publiée le 30 décembre 2015
biggest gripe / negative = single use checkpoint

it looks like a nice puzzle game, has some fun elements, but the checkpoint is bad. once you use a checkpoint, you can't "update" your checkpoint again so any new additional progress is wasted if you fall & die. this means that a simple misjump has you re-doing a bunch of stuff over and over again.

for me, it's too easy to get annoyed by that. and that makes the game not worth playing that much.

Recommandé
23.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 mai 2014
Probably one of the most atmospheric games I've ever played. Soundtrack fits pretty much perfectly with the world and its events. World looks mysterious and that leaves alot of space for speculations and theories. I really loved Portal & Portal 2, and this has some of the same aspects in the gameplay-wise, puzzles are getting progressively harder to solve, and you might even have to backtrack a bit in order to solve them, I played the original QBEH on desura, and I found it pretty enjoyable(for a student project). This although has some of the same levels, but enchanced, which makes it comfortable for me atleast. If you have played the original QBEH, and you are ready for another adventure with waAAaay more gameplay and tricks, you should definitely pick this up.

I liked the climbing parts the most, maybe because I really like platformers alot. I know some people who can't stand platformers at all, but the game is reasonable fair and gives checkpoints in the beginning of a trickier platforming part, I found it really neat for myself even, since I happened to fall off a couple times in those parts. :C

And the soundtrack was absolutely amazing aswell, I wouldn't have guessed that I would even pay attention to the soundtrack this much(I really don't pay attention to sounds that much in games), but this was pretty noticeable.

Anyways, TL;DR:

Very atmospherical game with a fitting soundtrack and clever puzzles, combined with fun and working game mechanics.

0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
3.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 février 2015
Wow, just wow. Let’s get started.

I – Story [10/10]

Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube is a first-person puzzle platformer from Liquid Flower. There is no real story in this game, nothing. Somehow though, you feel compelled to keep going, as if you just know there’s something greater going on behind the scenes. It’s a difficult thing to explain to someone who hasn’t experienced it first hand. The atmosphere is just amazing. I’ve never seen a game do something like this with so little. You really have to play it to understand what I’m saying.

II – UI [10/10]

The user interface is incredibly simple. Menus are bare-bones and well done. The HUD is very minimal to allow for a more complete sense of immersion. By way of HUD, you have a small dot reticle and some fading tabs that show you how many of each type of cube you currently have. Most of the time, you won’t even notice that it’s there.

III – Gameplay [9/10]

Playing Q1:TAC is an amazingly relaxing experience. Going into it, I had no idea what to expect beyond I was going to be solving puzzles. It’s so much more than that though in it’s entirety. The gameplay itself is as basic as can be. You can move around, move around slower, you can look at things, you can jump, and you can collect and place cubes in certain areas of the world. That’s all there is to it.

The puzzles are brilliant. There was a never a puzzle that I encountered that seemed impossibly hard. Some required more though and experimentation than others, but I was never overly frustrated by something. The only real problem that I had with Q1:TAC was the sparsely placed (and sometimes not very helpful) checkpoint locations. It didn’t detract from the game in the least, but it made things a bit tedious at times if mistakes were made.

IV – Content [9/10]

Rarely have I ever played a game with such a small amount of content that felt so very full. There are five types of cubes you can pick up and use in total and that’s it. (There are some secrets that you can find by exploring the levels, but you can’t do anything with those after you find them.) I would have liked to have seen a few more types of cubes, but it’s no big deal.

V – Visual [10/10]

Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube is a beautiful game. Merely rushing through it, trying to complete it as fast as possible is a disservice to yourself. Take the time to wander and enjoy all the beauty that the world of Q1:TAC has to offer. The environment is absolutely stunning (especially when it is coupled with the superb soundtrack).

VI – Audio [10/10]

If you ever play a game that has a soundtrack that syncs up with it more perfectly than Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube I demand that you notify me immediately. The music was, without a doubt, the best part of the entire game. You may have come here to solve puzzles and not to feel, but I will be damned if you make it out of this game without getting on the feels train at least once. Bravo to Launchable Socks to one of the best soundtracks I’ve ever heard (or felt) in a game.

VII – Overall [9.7/10]

Overall, Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube is more of a blissful, reflective experience than a game, and it is sheer brilliance. If you’re a fan of Portal, you’ll be into this. On sale or not, this one is worth every penny.
 
Surtr

Évaluation publiée le 30 aout 2015
Jogo com ótima trilha sonora, uma das melheores trilhas sonoras de jogos Indie que eu já ouvi, ótimos gráficos e um jogo de gênero puzzle 3D e que faz você se sentir que está num lugar tranquilo. Não é um jogo difícil, mas também não é tão fácil, mas você precisa ter paciência. O jogo não é tão curto como dizem, para você ZERAR todo o jogo demora muito tempo mesmo, pode ser finalizado em cerca de 8 horas ou mais, contudo para você encontrar todas as "pirãmides douradas" (são os itens secretos de cada fase) para liberar o mundo secreto leva bem mais tempo e exige que algumas fases sejam jogadas mais de uma vez. No geral é um ótimo jogo, recomendo comprar e jogar, além de que ele atualizou e adicionou o editor de fases com a workshop da Steam.

Évaluation publiée le 26 janvier 2017
Ein sehr entspanntes Puzzle Schrägstrich Jump&Run Spiel.
Für meinen Geschmack etwas zu entspannt; zumindest hätte man eine Sprintfunktion einbauen können. Lustigerweise gibt es auch laut Spiel sprinten aber ich nenne es Gehen-Mit-Ton, da das normale gehen genauso schnell ist aber eben ohne Schrittgeräusche.

Die Musik ist ebenfalls sehr entspannend und gut.

Allerdings hatte ich auch mit Bugs zu kämpfen. Zuerst einmal erfüllt mein Laptop alle Empfohlenen Vorraussetzungen des Spiels und trotzdem ruckelt es außer ich schalte auf eine sehr niedrige Auflösung.
Dann gibt es noch einen furchtbaren Bug der Auftritt, wenn man Blöcke zu schnell setzt. Diese verschwinden dann einfach und sind nicht mehr einsammelbar.

Insgesamt hatte ich aber meinen Spaß.

15.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 mai 2014
Bought this at 25% off regular price but this is well worth the sticker price of $9.99. The visuals are stunning and the puzzles are easy enough to keep most people interested but not so easy that you feel cheated. Of course the puzzles do get progressively more difficult but theres something satisfying about finally finding the solution.

There doesn't really seem to be any kind of storyline or supporting characters so if thats what your seeking look elsewhere. However, with the tranquille almost trancelike quality of the sound track, you'll quickly forget about storylines.

NOTE: I have not completed the game yet so if there is a storyline I appologise in advance to the devs and anyone reading this review.

If you like first person puzzle games and don't mind a slower pace or lack of supporting characters/storyline then this is a great buy for you. I do think it could do with a world builder and maybe some kind of stat/ranking system but other than that I really like this game and recommend you play it.

Recommandé
34.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 juin 2014
The experience, though obviously inspired by other first-person puzzle games, feels entirely new. It does the impossible: marrying relaxation with puzzles, without making those puzzles childishly simple.

Though the game relies on a relatively small pallet of environmental and graphical elements, it introduces them gradually enough that it continuously warrants (and rewards) those who like to explore, and especially those whose curiosity takes them outside the boundaries of the "normal" level path. Qbeh-1's difficulty ramps up considerably should you choose to search for its secrets. Though they're not essential, they do unlock extra levels, and the complex puzzles you must solve in order to find these secrets make them a reward in and of themselves. With or without the secrets, however, the difficulty level will increase as you reach the middle and end of the game; you are eased gently into this world, without feeling as though you're drudging through a tutorial. Once you learn the basics and begin craving more exploration, new elements (like gravity-defying jumps!) make your progress worthwhile and your journey fulfilling.

As in Antichamber, Perspective, The Bridge, and other great puzzle titles, the narrative is merely implied, and never treated to full exposition. I happen to love ambiguous stories, and if you feel the same way you'll find it very rewarding to piece the game's limited number of clues together.

Qbeh-1 is beautiful, therapeutic, and fun.

4.5/5
 
goodwithcomputr

Recommandé
51.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 septembre 2015
With the level editor FINALLY being implemented after so long, I can definitely recommend this game.
Even with the base content, it's definitely worth the $9.99 USD price tag. There are a total of 36 levels spread out around 6 'worlds', each with their own theme such as spring, winter, fall, summer, etc. Each level has a secret, which is a golden triangle, and if you manage to find all of them in worlds 1-5, world 6 will then unlock. In addition, there are a few extra secrets for achievements as well.
The gameplay is typical of puzzlers, starting out easy and getting progressively harder. However, it is also VERY fun, with four (technically five, but the fifth is a portal key to unlock the next world only found in the last level for each world) block types. The red cube, which is a structure block. The blue cube, which is a power block. The purple cube, which is a cube that reduces gravity in a certain range. And the green cube, which is a motor device that deteriorates after a certain distance. Typically, each world introduces a new block type, making the levels and designs more and more complex and challenging. Expect to fall out of the world to your death many times, this can be a very challenging puzzler.
The sounds and music are also superb. Each level has its own special music track, each as equally entrancing as the last. The musical score for this game is honestly amazing, and they also have the soundtrack available for purchase, which I will provide the link to (https://launchablesocks.bandcamp.com/album/qbeh-1-ost).
I can't leave out the graphics. For as simple as this game is, the visuals are honestly breathtaking. Lighting and shadowing are definitely the biggest strong points of this game graphically, and they never disappoint. Everything from the soft lighting on the blocks, the varying skyboxes, the flowing trees, and the glistening water all look the very best. If you're a sucker for that kind of thing, you might find yourself like I was, anticipating the next levels to see what lighting and graphics tricks they would apply next.
The only thing that's really any kind of drawback is the lack of a story whatsoever. There isn't necessarily an obvious point to the puzzling madness, but imo it's nothing major. It isn't what the selling point is anyway in any case.
Amazing game, definitely a must-buy for puzzle fans, particularly if it's ever on sale, and I'm very excited to play and build community levels.
 
Axolian
733 produits enregistrés

Recommandé
4.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 mai 2016
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a First person Puzzle game.


Interface/Menu/Settings

You are able to make your own level.
You are able to make multiple profiles for more then 1 user.
There are many resolution sizes.
You are able to play this game in fullscreen or windowed mode.
You are able to change the quality between Low and Very High.
You can change the volume of the Master Volume with a slidebar ( It shows the % )
You can change the volume of the Music Volume with a slidebar (it shows the %)
There is a sensitivty slidebar
You are able to use a Xbox controller.

About the game.

You are on a level trying to find "Red" Cubes in order to make a safe passage and reach the exit. You are able to place them in top of each other or on the Dark yellow blocks. You do need to take those blocks with you in order to complete the level. There are some checkpoints, so if you do die by falling off you are able to respawn here. However the checkpoint will only safe the progress that u have done already, Not after the checkpoint. What i do not understand is that you can't place those blocks below you. There has to be one cube connected to the Dark yellow block in order to make a Passage and you can't cut this away or else all blocks will transfer back into your pocket.


You are able to kill yourself by pressing a button and then hold that button.
You can't crouch but you can jump. Game REQUIRES alot of Jumping.
Puzzles are not too easy.
There is no Music in this game but there is a nice calming background soundtrack.
The game is very Athmospheric and it looks very good.
Graphics are good.
You are able to change your controls on the keyboard and xbox controller.


Other things.

There are Collectables, but they are not really fun to collect. The level on level selection will show Yellow, Once you have found them all in the level.

Running doesn't feel like Running.
The puzzles requires some thinking and if you can't do that, then im afraid the game isn't for you.

Best way to hear those collectables is turning off the music. The collectables are making some noise when you are near them.

You will lose the collectable if you have died and didnt found a checkpoint. So in order to keep it, you need to find a checkpoint so you can save that current progress.

-------------------

I Give this game a 7/10
 
Crafozura

0
Recommandé
8.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 aout 2014
a játék egy világ egyszerű logikai gém. egy kockákból álló lebegő inka jellegű templomszerűségekben kell bóklászgatni, és bizonyos speciális kockákat használva, azokból kijutni. többféle kocka áll a lehetőségre:
- van az általános narancs színű kockánk: amit fel tudunk ragasztani bizonyos helyekre, és ezáltal felugrálhatunk rá
- a kék kocka egy bizonyos kulcsként funkcionál, ami a legtöbb esetben ajtót nyit ki, vagy mozgó platformokat aktivizál
- a zöld kockát ugyanúgy hozzá tudjuk illeszteni a falhoz, de ez a kocka egy idő után megindul egy irányba, így nagyobb szakadékokon át tud vinni
- gravitációs kocka, ami talán a legjobb az egészben: egy teren belül a gravitáció lecsökken, és holdjáró módjára tudunk lépegetni

a pályák mint említettem kizárólag kockákból vannak összerakva. ez egy ideig fun, és jól néz ki, de a haramdik pálya után kicsit többre vágyna az ember. nagyon kevés tereptárgy található a játékban, ami nem kocka, így a pályák kinézete monoton. ez a tény azért is hátrány, mivel a játék nem használja ki a legújabb unity motor által adta lehetőségeket, és a kockákon nincs megfelelő árnyékkezelés, így sok helyen a sok egy színű kocka egybefolyik, és nincs térérzete az egésznek.

a játék techdemójával régebben játszottam. különlegessége, hogy tized ennyire sem volt nehéz benne egyetlen puzzle sem, valamint az akkor vásárolt gépemen brutál fps laggokat produkált. ez a jelenség sajnos még mindig meg van. habár 5 textúránál és 4 modellnél több nincs a pályán, mégis 500 és 50 között ugrál folyamatosan az fps.

a pályaszerkezetek és rejtvények teljesen korrektül vanank összehangolva, ami nem lehetett egyszerű feladat, hiszen sok esetben vissza kell térni egyes részekre, és újra körbemenni azért az egyetlen kis kulcsért. se nem nehezek, se nem könnyűek, habár a nehezségi szint teljesen random, nem fokozatosan nő a pályák előrehaladtával...ez talán nem feltétlenül róható fel negatívumként, inkább csak szubjektív tapasztalat.

a játék zenéjét túlságosan repetitívnek és egyszerűnek találtam. első hallásra nyugtatónak hat, de egy idő után sokszor idegesítővé válik amikor már ugyanazt a puzzlet fejtenéd meg 20-adjára.

a játékból iszonyatosan hiányolom a pályaszerkesztőt (plusz egy workshopot), mert a pályák újrajátszhatósága körülbelül egyenlő a semmivel. meg van bár a lehetőség, hogy egy extra bigyót megtalálhatunk minden pályán eldugva, de nem ad hozzá sokat a játékélményért. egy 7/10-et kap a gém, ajánlott, de csak leárazva.
 
mdv

5.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 mai 2014
If you love puzzles, and need something relaxing and laid back to play, this is your perfect choice. The atmosphere and the music of Qbeh-1 makes you want to keep playing; I've just spent about 5 hours on it without realizing what time was it, it was that fun.
Some puzzles can take several retries, but I never got stressed because of it, that's the magic of the music and the ambientation of the game; level design is simply amazing.
The price is just right, I'm enjoying every cent of it.

I'm glad Liquid Flower released this polished prequel of Qbeh, their college project, and I hope they keep bringing up more awesome games like this.

Évaluation publiée le 15 juillet 2017
Pros:
Fun puzzles/progression
Community seems to make a lot of cool levels

♥♥♥♥:
There are only so many ways to rehash the same puzzle concepts
Extraordinarily buggy. Some bugs are bizarre and stretch cubes to the end of time and other bugs actually make the game unplayable (Turning VSync off actually alters in game "ticks" which causes certain cubes to disappear twice as fast, rendering some puzzles impossible).
Beautiful game, but only runs at 30fps.

I'd recommend buying it if you are a sucker for puzzle games like me, but don't expect it to blow your socks off or be tremendously difficult.

Évaluation publiée le 17 aout 2015
Отличная головоломка с хорошей графикой и не менее отличной музыкой, которая сопровождает вас на всем пути)))). Разно образные урони не дадут вам заскучать, по началу простенькая и легенькая, но при дальнейшем прохождении заставит вас подумать и поломать немного мозг. Не смотря на свою простоту игра стоит того чтобы на нее обратили внимания)))) Советую всем кто любит поломать мозг и немного подумать))).
 
OraCOOL
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
33.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 mars 2018
First person puzzle games are a rare animal, and should be appreciated accordingly. However, there are very few that are done really and fully right - and unfortunately, many are downright bad. QBEH-1 is a specimen that reaches true greatness at times while just misses the "line of badness" at others.

As the game starts, you find yourself in a huge cube, made of smaller cubes. You need to navigate the big cube to the exit, and sometimes you are helped by... can you guess it? Yep, cubes. There are only a few types - the red buliding block (you can stand on it), the blue energy cube (operates mechanisms), the purple gravity cube (decreases gravity in an area), the white/grey master block (ends Worlds), and the green... I'll talk about it a bit later. Cubes attach only to special surfaces, giving the creators the freedom to create all kinds of crazy construction scenarios.
The visuals are simple but good-looking, the sounds are restrained and the music is OK. The great empty spaces create a unique atmosphere, and for the first levels, it propels you through the game easily. Difficulty increases gradually, and then an annoying phenomenon creeps in - some levels want you to do mild skill jumps. The controls are not very well prepared for this, and the sparseness of checkpoints often lead to having to repeat lengthy sections. And this reveals one weakness of the game - doing stuff in it is fun, but re-doing it is hideously boring. The creators explained the jump sections that they wanted to put a "fear of falling" experience in the game, which didn't make any sense to me at the time. Thanks to a few of these experiences, I abandoned the game on World 3 (out of 6).

Two years later, the game just popped up in my mind somehow, and I gave it another try. World 3 levels were still annyoing, but I somehow got through them, and things started to improve. Level 4-5's cheekily clever labyrinth, and level 4-6's outstanding atmosphere set the scene for World 5, which sees the introduction of the green cube, whose function is transport. With a green cube, you can travel approximately 20 cubes' distance into the direction the cube is set down. It's not hard to imagine where this cube combined with the gravity cube leads - at the end of level 5-1, I realized how very right the creators were with the whole fear of falling stuff. Most of World 5's levels are top notch, and I consider the 2-3 hours spent with them as my best 1st person puzzle experience since Portal 2.

Then you finish World 5, and you're looking for World 6 which you know is there, but you can't access it, because you need all the golden triangles (tokens) from the 30 levels of the 5 Worlds. Now, I do like exploring, but I only collected like 5-6 tokens, so I'm not sure how much merit is there in going through the levels once again to get the little buggers. The Internet helped me out to play World 6, which is mostly good but far from World 5.

I felt I can't review Qbeh-1 shortly, because with the genius parts and superb experience comes some definite pain. In this game you need to work really hard for the reward, and not for nothing there's a "Rage Quit" achievement in the game. With ample patience, you won't be disappointed - without it, you may drop the game without getting to the real good stuff.
 
gbors
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 mai 2014
Qbeh-1 is a good platformer. It's not bad, it's not terrible and it's certainly not amazing or astounding. It's just plain good and if you ask me - which you should since you're reading this - is something rather rare these days.

People always want to make the next best blockbuster that blows everyone's minds and generates billions of dollars and whatnot. Which, granted, is fine, I get that...but Qbeh feels a lot more humble and I like that. The atmosphere is created through level and audio design combined with a good colour palette, resulting in a solid foundation for a game.

It's serene and calm in the strange world of Qbeh. The slow and relaxed melodies combined with desolate but beautiful visuals gives a nice, pacifying feeling to the player. Playing this game relieves stress, well, personally speaking anyway, and I find that to a really nice and rare quality.

I highly recommend it. Not because of any action - there is none to be found. Not because of any electric guitar shredding - you're in the wrong neighborhood for that. Qbeh is a game of peace, exploration and a little brain work. When you're bored of blowing everybody up with explosives, riddling them with a hail of bullets or slashing zombies to bits, play this. It helps.

Évaluation publiée le 30 mai 2020
A fairly dated puzzle game that didn't grab me at all. It seems to mostly involve platforming and finding hidden objects rather than actual puzzles. The walk speed is so slow and the jump height is so shallow I was falling asleep. Experimentation is discouraged - you have to restart the entire level if you miss a jump. Pathways are unclear, puzzles have workarounds that weren't part of the design, puzzles that appear difficult can be solved easily by finding a stash of hidden cubes... the list goes on.

Recommandé
12.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 décembre 2014
I'll mainly write this from the perspective as an Oculus Rift user and how I experienced this game in VR.

Qbeh-1 is a puzzle game with pretty straightfoward mechanics, taking place in simplistic but atmospheric environments. The music and presentation make it very enjoyable to play in VR. The fact there is a hidden token in every level also encourages you to be aware of your environment and spot hidden routes.

However there are a few downsides for the VR player at the moment:

* Movement isn't too VR friendly. This is mainly because of the continous turning of the player instead of having the option to enable incremental turning (the aptly named "VR comfort mode" pioneered by Cloudhead Games). Jumping might feel a bit abrupt too and can be a bit heavy on the stomach for those that are sensitive to it. I'd recommended new VR users to acclimate to VR a bit with other demos before jumping into this game.
* Framedrops in some levels. Even on my high-end rig, some of the larger levels dip below the recommended 75 fps for some reason (while my CPU and GPU remain underutilized). This could be in part due to the current Oculus drivers and the performance impact of using the Rift's Direct Mode, but anyway, it ruins the experience.
* Some spots in the game might require you to stretch your neck a bit in order to reach spots that are right above you (and might make your headphones fall off, as in my case). This is to be expected if the game wasn't initially designed with VR in mind, but it's still playable. Just something to keep in mind.

Non recommandé
4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 décembre 2017
I kind of wish I could recommend this game, but I just can't. As others have said, it's not so much a puzzle game as it is a jumping trial.

I played about halfway through (3 worlds). When you get to the third cube type (gravity cube), there is a moment of relief: is the game finally going to pick up the pace? But unfortunately, it seems, no. The game is just a bit too boring and repetitive. The new mechanics (cube types) should be introduced much faster and all the obvious levels just scrapped completely. The slow movement speed is not helping at all. I didn't fall that many times so personally the jumping wasn't that much of a deal breaker to me, it's just boring.

Non recommandé
21.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 juin 2015
Ждал хорошей головоломки, получил лабиринт =(

Все задачи решаются интуитивно понятно или методом тыка. Единственная сложность это сориентироваться на карте в первые пару минут (не знаешь с чего начать).

В игре есть спрятанные предметы (марки), чтобы их найти приходится лезть во все возможные щели, тратя много времени. А я вроде головоломку покупал, зачем мне поиск спрятанных вещей? Описание игры некорректно!

Разочарован игрой, зря потраченное время и деньги. Ожидал большего. Уровень сложности головоломок для детей дошкольного возраста.

Если вы поклонник таких головоломок как Portal или Braid, эта игра вам мало даст. Не повторяйте моих ошибок.

Общая оценка головоломки: 2 из 10.
 
Aunmag
187 produits enregistrés

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
25.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 avril 2016
I really tried hard to like this game. I love Portal and The Swapper and tons of other puzzle games, but ultimately this game failed me because the platforming elements vastly overwhelmed the puzzle elements. I would say that this game is 90+% dexterity, which is way too high for an ostensible puzzle game. Much of the dexterity consists of precise jumps, which, if you fail, mean you have to restart at the previous checkpoint. You can't save the game just before a jump; the checkpoints are fixed, and very far between, so missing a jump means redoing a big chunk of the game, which gets really boring really fast. Also, when you have made a structure out of blocks and are standing on it, very often you have to add a block right next to the block you are standing on, which requires extremely precise control or you will fall off the structure, requiring you to start over, which is just bad game design. The puzzles (such as they are) are usually pretty trivial; most of the time if you can't solve one it's because you didn't see some place where a cube could go. Finally, the game is just plain monotonous, and finishing a level feels like a chore. The graphics are gorgeous and the music is nice and serene (though I ended up turning it off anyway), but the flaws in this game make it not worth your time. This isn't a Zen-like game at all; it just looks like one. It's actually aggravating and frustrating. Perhaps if you consider walking on a tightrope over a canyon to be Zen-like, you will like this game. Otherwise, look elsewhere.

Évaluation publiée le 22 décembre 2019
セールで購入。
進行度は半分行ったくらいでしょうか。
ブロック個数＆設置制限のあるマインクラフトで脱出する面クリアタイプ。
床の無い所へ落下・圧死・接触死でチェックポイントかスタートに戻ります。
グラフィック・音楽◎。
一部素早い操作を求められることもありますが
基本足場を組んでの移動とドアキー探しに時間を費やします。
とても面白いのですが、あえて欠点を挙げるとすれば
・後半の面は長時間かかるのに途中でゲームを止めてもチェックポイントから再開できない事
・例えばチェックポイント後に特定のドアを通過して死ぬと再開時にドアが通れなくなって詰む
またはチェックポイントを別のチェックポイントで上書きしてしまい詰む
ですかね。

349 produits enregistrés

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
25.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 novembre 2018
Amazing ambiance for a first-person puzzle solving game. Despite not really having a story, per se, the gameplay was honestly enjoyable enough that it didn't need one. I also want to point out that I was pleasantly surprised with each special cube that was introduced throughout the game. The efficiency and sound effects of placing and collecting cubes were also very satisfying.

You really get used to looking at the world and understanding what you can accomplish with the set of cubes on hand. So much so that I didn't really mind replaying most of the levels when combing through to Find all the Golden Pyramids and unlock the hidden World 6.

If you're a fan of the Portal 2 Community Levels that introduce new testing elements, I think this one is definitely worth playing.

114.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 novembre 2017
Yes. Yes. This game is Yes. The premise is collecting and using various types of cubes to get to an exit. Some cubes are building blocks, keys, transport pads, low-gravity, etc. It's not quite Portal, Magrunner, QUBE, Rush ... it's a little of each.

When you finish the game, check out the Community Made levels: There are a TON of them! Make sure that you check the fan ratings on them first ... one of the Steam achievements is creating and uploading a level of your own, and a lot of people threw in lackluster broken ones.

Recommandé
59.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 mai 2016
Игра супер.Это самая удачная игра издателя (разрабочтика) с моей точки зрения. Странно, что о ней мало слышно. В игре всё шикарно: музыка, под которую уходишь в медитативное состояние; графика, которая минималистична и в тоже время не режет глаза, головоломки, не мега сложные и в то же время не простые. Ради бога! Не нужно её сравнивать с portal и прочими играми данного жанра. Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube - самодостаточна, оригинальна и имеет хороший потенциал при должном внимании. Её можно оценить по достоинству, если погрузиться в идею автора, прочувствовать её и расслабиться. Очень радует, что есть мастерская уровней и уже достаточно большое количество созданных карт инициативными ребятами. Хотелось бы, чтобы добавили steam cloud, русский язык (хотя посути он там не нужен - в игре нет диалогов и не нужно ничего читать, кроме меню игры) и доработали редактор карт(он немного сыроват, на первый взгляд).

Évaluation publiée le 16 décembre 2015
This is an interesting game, the levels have a decent amount of replay value especially if you are someone that likes to 100% games, the level editor is quite fun but can be difficult to use. The community does not have many level at the moment so you can get all to many new maps after you have finished the main game.
I would definitely recommend this game, it's got clever puzzles that are not all to difficult at the beginning but begin to become increasingly difficult.
Overall this game is definitely worth a purchase if you like puzzle games but if you don't i would recommend getting it from a sale.
 
shock

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
12.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 octobre 2015
Solidní logická hra kombinovaná s průměrným platformerem. Právě z toho druhého pramení jistá frustrace - skákání je rychlé a nepříliš přesné a nepovedený skok většinou končí smrtí a restartem od checkpointu (těch je někdy dost a jindy málo).
Další potíž je repetitivita. Herní prostředí je celou hru úplně stejné, jen se měni obloha, osvětlení a ambientní efekty. A herních mechanik je jen pár: čtyři druhy kostek a větráky. To je na 36 herních úrovní opravdu málo.
Každý level skrývá právě jeden skrytý pyramidální token a pokud sesbíráte všechny tokeny v pěti světech, otevře se vám tajný šestý svět. Sbírání tokenů je ale záležitost jen pro masochisty. Bývají opravdu dobře schované s minimem indicií, přístup k nim je obtížný a pokud po sebrání tokenu zemřete dřív než uložíte u checkpointu, token se vrátí na své místo a musíte ho jít sebrat znovu.
Verdikt: Velmi mírný palec nahoru.

Rias Gremory
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
23.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 février 2022
This starts really nicely but falls flat with its extremely tedious and repetitive puzzles. It's actually not much of a puzzle really, there were a couple "wait how do I even get there" moments for me across the 36 long levels but that's about it. It's a linear walking simulator with jumping and cube-stacking involved. Pick a cube, use it to access more cubes, then use them to advance to the next area while leaving some cubes behind, repeat this a few times, exit the level. There is also no story whatsoever. You just kind of... jump your way through all the levels and call it a day.

And then there's all the frustration with how the game is designed...

- You come to a T-junction. Go left, advance through a puzzle, get to the end of it but there's a locked door. Go back, take the right turn, solve another puzzle and be awared with a key. So go left again, solve the first puzzle again and finally open the door to proceed. >_<

- Use various cubes to climb a vertical wall. There's a key above. But the door's below. Jump down, die from fall damage that you didn't know exists, reset to checkpoint. Climb again, grab the key, descend carefully, open the door. It reveals another key, so you now have two keys and there's another door that also needs two keys. And it's located above. So you climb the wall for the third time. >_<

- You apply significant patience, creativity and skill in getting out of a puzzle while preserving more cubes than you should normally be able to carry out of it. You use them to get out of the map bounds elsewhere and explore around, having to constantly restart from checkpoint because you jump down into dead ends you can't get out from. Turns out the secret is located in one particular dead end of those. Or, better yet, it just was behind the exit portal all along. >_<

- You enter a new area and it's really dark, which is annoying and it makes looking for secrets a lot more difficult. So you go to the video settings aaaaand there are no brightness/gamma options. >_<

- You put a cube onto a wall, but it glitches out and disappears. Depending on how late into the level this was you may or may not be boned, but you'll likely have restart from the checkpoint. This happened over a dozen times on my playthrough. >_<

Fun for about an hour but drags itself out for just so, so insanely long. I would have dropped the game ten times over if it wasn't for my really unhealthy pursuit of 100% achievements. Which given my 23 hour investment into this game was absolutely not worth it and not fun. Please send help
 
Rushin'
538 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 janvier 2019
Un puzzle game mâtiné de plateforme, sympathique mais qui manque de caractère. Pas d'histoire ; simplement une succession de niveaux à la difficulté croissante. Les structures sur lesquelles l'on évolue sont le plus souvent suspendues dans le ciel, quelques-unes étant cloisonnées. Il n'y a pas de dégâts de chute, mais l'on peut tout de même tomber dans le vide.

Le but est toujours le même : récupérer des cubes de différentes couleurs et aux différentes propriétés, afin de les placer à des endroits spécifiques marqués en jaune et ainsi progresser jusqu'au portail de fin de niveau. Les premiers cubes que l'on trouvera n'ont d'autre utilité que d'être empilés afin d'atteindre des hauteurs autrement inaccessibles, mais ensuite, d'autres peuvent servir à déverouiller des portes, à réduire la gravité pour sauter plus loin ou constituer des plateformes mobiles.
Le petit défi en plus, facultatif mais amusant, c'est de trouver le petit triangle doré caché dans chacun des niveaux du jeu. On le fait au départ avec plaisir, mais passé le premier tiers, les niveaux se corsent en plus de se rallonger – un peu trop peut-être. Si 5 minutes suffisent pour la première section, cela finira par monter jusqu'à 1 demi-heure, voir plus. C'est beaucoup pour un jeu qui se veux avant tout paisible, aidé en cela par une musique vraiment douce et planante.

QBEH est donc un jeu en deux temps. Agréable et peu prise de tête au début, il vous passera le temps agréablement. Mais vous ne finirez sans doute pas le dernier tiers, sauf à être complétiste.
 
Nockeim
493 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
19.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 janvier 2019
I'm currently done with the game and i do have to say this is among the best hidden gems on steam in terms of puzzle games. each stage manage to mix up how you have to build your way though the stage of each world. the game gives off this lonesome atmosphere of being trapped in a endless void of cubes. the music highlights this REALLY well. delivering calmful pieces that allow the player to focus on competing many of the levels and their challenges that are ahead. have i also talked about the fact that this game has steam workshop support. meaning you can preety much be playing this game for a long time thanks to user created content. the game doesnt really have any story elements. which im fine since i mostly play puzzles games with the intention of playing for the puzzles anyway and this game does that with flying colors and cubes. this was the best blind buy ive made and the perfect game to unwind after a busy day from work. I recommand this game if you are fan of portal! ( and speaking of that, you run into a "old friend" while playing. when you see your "friend." you'll know. :) Or if you love puzzle games as a whole.

Non recommandé
1.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 juillet 2017
I played it a little bit. Puzzles so far seem trivial. World 1 level 6 I find a white block with blueish pattern. But the game doesn't allow me to place it in the spot it's supposed to go.
Looking through the forums I find that it happens often. Restarting the game is supposed to help. After restarting the game I am back at the start of the level (and not the savepoint I reached).
And now I can't even place the red blocks.

Also it changes screen resolution whenever I go to settings and setting keybindings does not seem to work. The preset key for running does not work. I am using two screens and every now and then the window jumps so that it covers half of each screen.

At this point I am returning the game...
 
Firedancer
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
42.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 octobre 2019
Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube - малопопулярная игра от Liquid Flower. Игра не лучше Portal, Q.U.B.E. и Twin Sector, уровни маленькие, сюжет весьма смутный, а о багах можно писать длинные статьи (и возможно напишу). Но знаете что заставило меня 5 раз перепроходить игру, собирать все достижения и от всей души наслаждаться этой игрой? Тогда слушайте;
Во первых: расслабляющая музыка которая нежно опутывает игрока во время прохождения игры
Во вторых: Дизайн уровней просто великолепен. Создается ощущение что мы реально прыгаем по руинам застывших над бездной (Даже не представляю какие эмоции испытывают люди играющие в шлемах виртуальной реальности)
В третьих: Простота геймплея играет этой медитативной игрушке только на руку, позволяя неспешно прогуляться по уровням в поисках секреток (по типу куба компаньона из Portal и мини пирамиды из песка) или использовав глюки прогуляться по крышам строений
Игру настоятельно рекомендую, так как помимо 6 кубов по 6 уровней в каждом, в игре есть мастерская с редактором уровней, так что у вас даже после прохождения игры найдется чем в ней заняться
10 грави-кубов из 10

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Non recommandé
1.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 juillet 2018
Produit remboursé

This game tries too hard on being "ambiency" the music sounds like those meditation tracks but sometimes it is too jarring for it.
Gameplay loop boils down to:
1. Start the level with nothing
2. Find a red cube or do a jump puzzle to get some
3. Look behind to get them back
4. Use blue key cubes to open door/activate moving platform (usually it is provided a new one for the next puzzle if you had to leave it behind)

The enviroment is "oohh mysterious crumbling ancient ruins falling apart" it was quite catching at first, but I realized it was just visual filler to hide how bland and simple this game is.
Sometimes in dark areas I counldn't see what I was bumping into.

The first zone was entirely just "fill the steps of an incomplete ladder or bridge", well, the second zone was zone 1 + key cubes in different order of execution, just incresingly number of the same steps over and over. There was some creative puzzles, but I cannot remember more than those 2 in my mind.

This game is something any hobbyist could do in a browser flash puzzle game.
 
Awri Lynn
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
12.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 aout 2016
Simplistic First Person platforming puzzle game.

I bought this game on a whim, and I have no regrets.
If you're interested in games like Portal or Trine, this game is for you.
You'll be able to adapt to every situation after a quick analysis of what's laid out on the table.
Puzzles do not jump quickly in difficulty, they scale extremely well as you progress.
The game presents a very calming atmosphere that will keep your mind at ease as you build your path to success.
If you're feeling up for a challenge, there are hidden pyramids in each level that will give completionists a very satisfying feeling.

After completing the game, feel free to take a look at the Steam Workshop, as it has quite the active community.

Please give this beautiful game your time.

Évaluation publiée le 11 janvier 2017
Everything I love about puzzle platformers is in this game. The exploration, the creative ways of solving the puzzles (sometimes bypassing them entirely with well placed jumps). The music is phenomenal, and I had a lot of fun tracking down the easter eggs (still a few to go).

I would love to see a sequel to this game.

I highly recommend this title to anyone that enjoys platformers.

๋⁧⁧<zeexh/>
595 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
35.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 juin 2017
Excellent puzzle platformer with minecraft-y level design where you have to use a combination of 4 different kinds of cubes to get from point a to point b. you place cubes on special tiles in the level which accomplish different tasks (red is just a block, blue is a key/activates things, purple reduces gravity in a set area and green moves a limited distance) all on levels which are surrealist and floating high up in the stratosphere. the style of the levels almost remind me of the temples from Journey or Abzu and the soundtrack is a nice mellow ambient that is repetitive but manages to not get obnoxious (minus one or two levels.) some of my favorite parts of the game would have to be the shadow underneath your character, which, for anyone who has played a first person game where you can't see your feet, this is a godsend when dealing with narrow ledges. another great part about it is the ability to "break" the game as i call it, or manage to escape the bounds of what the developers intended to be the playing field by finding a way on top of the level and finding all sorts of easter eggs or finding new ways to bypass entire parts of the levels just by using a little creative thinking.
all in all a great game, and plenty of community levels if you're into that. give it a shot if you're a puzzle platform fan

0
Non recommandé
1.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 décembre 2018
Qbeh-1 is one of those games that really make you appreciate good puzzle game design. Unfortunately, this is because "You don't know what you got 'til it's gone."
I quit halfway through the second world, so I don't know what kind of other cubes/mechanics get introduced later on, but the beginning gave me a bad taste. The "puzzles" in world 1 are nothing but picking up cubes and placing them in dedicated zones to reach more cubes to increase your supply to repeat ad nauseum. It gets old quick, especially with the great many instakill pits that respawn you at FAR-too-infrequent checkpoints, forcing you to repeat the earlier tediousness. The puzzle design might be redeemable later on with more mechanics, but the QoL here is too low for me to recommend.

This is a pretty wonderful puzzle game, the difficulty is manageable, the soundtrack is great, the game is really pretty, and you can accomplish the puzzles in some out there ways (I ended up traversing the entirety of the outside of one stage, places I wasn't even supposed to be able to go, to get the secret and complete the stage, just through sheer will and stupid ideas on how to complete the puzzle). I greatly recommend it and you can get the soundtrack here: https://launchablesocks.bandcamp.com/album/qbeh-1-ost . If you end up purchasing the game, I hope you enjoy it as much as I did.

Évaluation publiée le 3 juin 2017
uno de los mejores de puzzles que he jugado. Buenos gráficos.
Engancha bastante conforme se avanza en los niveles, ♥♥♥ mayor complejidad y dificultad, ya que hay que tener mucha habilidad manejando el teclado para saltar, flotar, voltearse simultáneamente, para no caer al vacío.
En síntesis, en cada nivel hay que encontrar la puerta de salida, en un laberinto formado por cubos, algunos (de colores) tienen propiedades especiales, que habrá que usar según el caso: para hacer puentes, subir del planta, ...
Un dinero bien gastado.

 
szandor5
0
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 juin 2015
One of the best games I've played in a while. I love this game. It is a Portal like game, but without portals. You are the only being in this mysterious world, and your objective is to get to the exit in each room.

Now, after beating the first world, I realized I only picked up one pyramid. I went back to level 1 to start finding the other 5 in the first world, and I have to say, they are really tricky to get to. They are usually in a hidden room that you won't normally see. Now those made the game for me!

The game is good at leading you in the right direction, except for the pyramids, those are a lot harder to find. But to simply get to the exit, you can usually just follow the paths and do the jump puzzles.

Basically, you pick up these red blocks and use them to get to places. You can climb them, walk across them, create stairs, whatever you need, as long as you have enough. There are climbing puzzles where there is a huge wall, and you have to somehow climb up to the edge.

I love the graphics, I love the music, I love the atmosphere, I love the Portal like world. You are the only being, and you are trying to simply get to the end of each level.

When I say these graphics are better than COD, I mean it. I know that's a joke that goes around, but I was shocked to see these graphics on Very High with MSAA turned on. Advanced Warfare was a million dollar game and doesn't look as good as this.

Great job guys! One of the best indie games I've played in a long time.
 
Sympathy For The Devil
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 juillet 2020
Tiene un gran Aire al Portal, Qube, Antichamber y ReThink.

Tenes Piramides (secretos) 1 por nivel, 6 mundos diferentes y 33 niveles en total entre ellos.

Excelente musica, ambientacion, iluminacion, sonidos, jugabilidad simple, Corto pero a la vez altamente rejugable.

Tus objetos son cajas añadibles a secciones de pared, techo o pisos (son amarillas y brillantes, se añaden de a uno), los puzzles consisten en eso y salir por un portal de luz, se debe saltar bastante y esquivar algunos obstaculos, esta bastante ingenioso.

Tus objetos son 5 tipos de cajas:
Caja de Portal (Abre el portal para salir)
Caja de Puertas/plataformas (Abre puertas o activa plataformas)
Caja de Gravedad (Permite una zona de baja gravedad para saltar o caer)
Caja Comun (nada especial, solo para caminar o saltar en ella)
Caja de transporte (Verde, se transporta en el aire hacia la direccion en la que esta viendo la fila que construis)

Las vas encontrando por el mapa y tenes que ir usandolas y recuperandolas para poder continuar ♥♥♥ tu travesia hasta el final.

Pocos requerimientos, Muy buenos graficos, De Ingenio, totalmente recomendable --- 9/10

TIPS: Podes trabar plataformas ♥♥♥ cajas, podes usar cualquier caja como soporte para saltar, tenes que trabar ventiladores para no caerte, las cajas verdes se destruyen pero en los lugares donde las encontras si tienen una marca verde, vuelven a regenerarse, podes retirar las cajas y las plataformas van para atras asi recuperas la caja (En algunos escenarios, y debes saltar rapido, ya te vas a dar cuenta)

1,124 produits enregistrés

4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Non recommandé
1.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 novembre 2015
I picked this up looking for a relaxing puzzler.

The music and art style are certainly relaxing, but the gameplay is anything but. The entire challenge comes from precision jumping onto small blocks. One wrong step at any moment could mean your death, creating a persistant atmosphere of tension and dread.

This is easily the most stressful game I've played - and I love psychological horror games.

If you suffer any degree of acrophobia, don't even think about it.
 
Starchild
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
9.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 mars 2015
Несмотря на отсутствие механизмов (исправление: механизмы присутствуют!) и зримого влияния неведомых культур, я бы отнесла эту игру к жанру Myst. В одной статье я прочла мнение, что часть составляющей успеха Myst - в том, что это "туризм", посещение неведомой земли со своими аборигенами. В Qbeh-1 атмосфера похожая (кстати, читается "Кьюба минус один" - приквел к игре Qbeh, написанной автором в студенческие годы). Первый мир - светлый, солнечный. Вид неба и закатов, вращающейся под ногами планеты захватывает. Разве что всё-таки не могу порекомендовать игру тем, кто боится высоты или восприимчив к одиночеству. В разрушающихся воздушных храмах совершенно безлюдно, словно это ветшающие остатки древней одухотворённой цивилизации над необитаемой планетой. Второй мир навевает совершенно другую атмосферу, чем первый. Что будет потом - посмотрим; но насколько я понимаю, это одна из игр, у которых нет конкретной предыстории, и игроку предлагается интерпретировать подсказки самостоятельно.

Если игра понравилась, рекомендую после неё попробовать Kairo.
 
Katemare
1,559 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
60.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 novembre 2018
マインクラフトのパズルアクション

パズルよりアクション要素が強い

良い所
なじみのある世界観と操作性
良BGM

悪い所
３D酔いしやすい
移動しながらブロックを置く時にタイミングが悪いとブロックが消失する。（他の場所に移動かも）
ステージによってBGMの大きさが異なり音量調整が必要
移動速度がちょっと遅い

Recommandé
17.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 janvier 2016
Think 3D puzzle maze and you've got a fairly decent description of this game, but you'd be missing on a few key aspects

Qbeh-1 is a first person puzzle platformer that places the player on a structure floating in the upper atmosphere with only one goal: reach the doorway at the end of the area. In order to get there, you'll use various cubes to open doors, reduce the effects of gravity, or raise yourself to new heights. There is no narrative to this game so you'll not find any purpose to your level progression and puzzles really aren't that complicated, but the levels themselves are extraordinarily fun to explore.

Each world is set over a gorgeous sky scape that changes from level to level. Some levels show bright blue of mid-day, others the darkness of night, and still more the orange hues of sunrise and sunset. The lighting within each level is built to reflect the setting outside, so you really feel like you're immersed in the level. It all combines to make a very peaceful game-playing experience.


Puzzle design:
I felt every level could have been more difficult. The game practically throws cubes at you, so you never actually have to worry about using your cubes judiciously and picking them up when you're done. I'd say the puzzle aspect of this game could have been much improved if the game actually made you think about how to build a stairway with 4 cubes, rather than giving you 10 cubes to make your way up. One or two levels early on actually did make you build stairs with only 3 cubes, and that proved to be a fun and challenging puzzle.

The first world starts you off with only one type of cube that you will use to add to the structure of the world, enabling you to progress to the exit. Subsequent worlds slowly introduce new cubes and you're ability to affect your surroundings slowly begins to expand. The difficulty ramps up smoothly as you progress, but never reaches a point that casual players would find frustrating.


Level design:
I would say that I had more fun exploring the levels than I did actually solving their puzzles. This game gives you a lot to explore, and it rewards exploration with secrets that you can find in every level. I was constantly looking for gaps in the wall that were at least 3 cubes tall (that's the size you can fit through) or for ways to jump to higher levels. I often found myself standing on the wall of a level looking down on where I previously trekked just to see if I somehow missed the hidden pyramid.

Of the secret pyramids I found, my favorite was probably the one that had a switch underneath the floor right before the exit. There was a small crack in the ground that was barely noticeable, but if you put a cube on the switch, a platform would lower and you could get the pyramid. However, you couldn't get back up to the exit unless you saved all your cubes earlier in the level, so I felt doubly rewarded for being observant and for being stingy on my cubes!

The checkpoint feature in each level is a bit too unforgiving. Rather than remember the farthest you've reached, the checkpoints reset to the most recent one you pass, so a small slip off a platform could force you to restart a level if you land near a checkpoint but left all your cubes above you. (This happened to me more than once!)

One caution I would say about exploration is that the game not often but occasionally punishes you for exploring. A few times I ended up on a platform that I couldn't jump out of simply because all the walls were 2 cubes high (you can only jump up 1 cube height).


Community workshop:
Qbeh-1 features a level creator in case you want to try your own hand at creating some levels, or if you want to try what others have designed. I tried a handful of community-made levels, but didn't like any of them. Seems like people just want to make levels ridiculously complicated or are just trying to create the minimum amount necessary to get the Steam achievement. I don't know if I'll ever come back and make my own, but I probably won't play any more anytime soon.


Minor grievances:
The level selection map has probably the poorest design I've ever seen in a game. Each world is represented as a cube, and you have to rotate the cube until you find the side that corresponds with the level you want to play, but the cube faces aren't numbered.

There is also a glitch that allows you to use the effect of the purple low gravity cube without actually attaching it to a wall. I stumbled across this early on but played through the game without it because let's be honest, cheating your way through a game on the first play really isn't all that fun.

The later levels have a lot of empty hallways that serve no purpose to the level other than to increase the time you spend walking in circles. I like to explore, but a boring circular hallway isn't what I'm looking for.


Final thoughts: 8/10
This game is entirely about discovery, and the developers put a lot of creativity together to present you with a fantastic world to explore. This game was definitely created with casual players in mind, but I'd say anyone who wants to play a relaxing game with beautiful atmosphere and puzzles nearly reminiscent of Zelda would enjoy Qbeh-1 immensely!
 
wizcreations
912 produits enregistrés
1

Évaluation publiée le 17 juin 2019
Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube

=== [Player Base: ] ===
☑ Casual players
☐ Hardcore players


===[]===
☐ Kids
☐ Teens
☐ Adults
☑ Everyone
☐ Mature


===[] ===
☑ Doesn't have it
☐ Bad
☐ Average
☐ Good
☐ Fantastic


===[]===
☐ Really bad
☐ Bad
☐ OK
☑ Good
☐ Beautiful
☐ Masterpiece


===[]===
☐ Easy Peasy
☐ Easy to learn but hard to master
☑ Medium
☐ Hard
☐ Dark Souls


===[]===
☐ Really short ( 0 - 2 hours)
☐ Short ( 2 - 8 hours)
☑ Average ( 8 - 12 hours)
☐ Long ( 12+ hours)
☐ Endless


===[]===
☐ Toaster
☑ Average
☐ Solid Medium
☐ High end
☐ Unoptimized


===[]===
☐ Full price
☑ Wait for sale
☐ Don't do it
☐ Free


===[]===
☐ Game itself is a bug
☐ Lot of bugs
☐ Few Bugs
☑ Nothing

Gameplay
QBEH-1: The Atlas Cube is an atmospheric 1st-person puzzle plat-former by Liquid Flower that takes players on an inspired quest through a variety of divergent worlds, each filled with new mysteries and secrets to uncover. In each world, players find special cubes that must be collected and used to navigate to the next portal

Review
A very simple layout for a complex game, Tetris and Minecraft spring to mind when first played. The game is not at all hard, just requires a little brain power to figure out this beautiful puzzle. The game does go a little stale after the first few worlds but it doesn't take away how good the puzzles are, buying this on sale would be the best approach.

How annoying are those green cubes?

■■■■■■□□□□ 6 / 10

Recommandé
2.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 novembre 2017
很早就想推荐这款游戏了

第一次是离线玩的，无论是画面制作，游戏创意，还是操作手感都是同类型一流水平。
尤其是游戏的BGM：空灵、剔透、恰到好处，画面感很强，令人富于联想。
游戏是第一人称视角，流程挺长，考验操作，对于FPS玩家应该不成问题。
支持创意工坊，有很多高玩的优秀作品可以体验。另外成就系统也蛮有趣，富于挑战性，想全成就不太容易。

游戏每关都有一个隐藏的金色三角椎，一般都在很难被察觉的角落里，接近时会有特殊音效，算是提示。

有的位置简直意想不到，但细想其实又都合情合理。充分结合了地图，身法以及逻辑链条的因素，非常耐人寻味。

所以通关并不算什么，能把所有金三角都找到才算本事

( PS：游戏有流程视频，实在过不去的时候可以参考，但还是建议大家自己尝试，毕竟有时难度=成就感 )
 
無相佈施

Personalmente me esta gustando bastante este juego, un poco antichamber, y un poco mirrors edge(sin accion).

Évaluation publiée le 3 octobre 2017
Produit remboursé

讲真，我是被评论区某人说玩MC玩到无聊，然后推荐这个，才买的。。。

然后。。。我玩了。。。感觉。。。

作者在地图和背景上面的确做得不错，氛围和天马行空的想象我也赞同，但是总感觉就是个MC跑酷+解密地图完全可以做到的么。。。我不是地图作者，但玩过几个地图，感觉完全可以做到。

跑回去玩我的MC去了。。。

不过，抛开这些（毕竟MC和这个本来就不是一类游戏，不可比，不可比），这游戏作为一个休闲解密类游戏还是非常好玩的，打折5元的价格，物超所值了，还是推荐

Non recommandé
0.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 mars 2015
AVOID IF YOU HAVE FEAR OF HEIGHTS. That's obviously not going to apply to everyone, but, it did to me. The trailer somewhat indicates that the game is set way up in the sky, but it doesn't really communicate the fact that a large amount of it involves leaping across destroyed floors above endless pits.

That's actually some what of a relevant complaint for everyone else too: I came into this expecting something like Antichamber (which it shares at least one mechanic with), and while it is a mostly puzzle-focused game, there is a much larger focus on precision platforming than I was expecting. (And in a somewhat poor choice, a single misstep often means you have to replay an entire, fairly large portion of the level all over again.)

As for the VR support, I haven't even been able to get it to work, but a game with this much stop-and-start jumping seems like a poor choice for VR anyway.
 
RavenWorks

Recommandé
14.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 mai 2015
不思議な世界観のFPSパズルゲーム
ルールは単純に言うとアンチチェンバー的な感じで、ブロックを置いて足場にしたりドア開けたりして進むゲーム
ステージ数は６×６ワールドで、各ステージに取るの必須的な隠しアイテムが一個ずつある（さらにその他にシークレット的なやつがちらほらあるっぽい）
隠しの隠し方はどれも秀逸で、信じられないルートを通っていかないと大体取れない
ところがこれが曲者で、マップはどこも落ちたら即死の状態で隠しルートを探さなければならないので、色んなところにジャンプして試行錯誤しながら探したいんだけど
クイックセーブがなく、セーブポイントの間隔も変に遠く、しかも一度セーブするとそのセーブポイントは使えないという謎仕様のせいで全然試行錯誤する気が起きない
隠しがあるかないかを探すのになぜいちいち最初に戻されなきゃいけないのか
全体的にアクション性が高すぎて解法がわかっても落ちて死んでいちいち最初に戻されることが多すぎる
詰み防止のセーブポイントなのかと思ったけど全然そんなことはなく普通に詰みます
なのでまあアクションパズルとして隠しは動画を見て確認しながら楽しむのが一番だと思います
雰囲気はいいので老後にぜひ
 
yuuutu

様々な効果を持った箱(ギミック作動、範囲内の重力減少など)を使いながらゴールを目指す、ステージクリア型のパズルアクションです。

パズル自体もそれなりに考えさせられることもあり、また各ステージに隠し要素(?)となるものが隠されている点もGoodでした。
お値段以上に遊べたと思います。雰囲気ゲー好きにはオススメです。
