Évaluation publiée le 20 mars 2015
You need to be specific about your expectations when you look for a game to buy.

Having said that, this game is definitely worth its money, if you're looking for something action-packed with lots of stuff going on or something heavily reliant on a plot, turn back now because this isn't what you're looking for, however if you expect something lightweight that puts your thinking skills as well as coordination to the test then you'll get your fill with this game.
The game itself is well put together as every element of it harmoniously comes together into a relaxing and soothing experience, if anything I'd compare this game to a day off when you don't go to work or school and just pamper youself all day.
I'll rate this 4/5
why not a 5? because I believe that its a little short, it has some replay value as you explore and revisit the same places to find the hidden items if you haven't done that in your first run however it's a shame that the people who made this game didn't add some sort of level editor so that people could make and share their own levels online.
 
Young Discord
2
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 mars 2015
The atmosphere in this is brilliant in its simplicity, the controls are effective... the game just needs actual puzzles. Qbeh doesn't subscribe to the "Portal" school of puzzles, where the puzzle elements are clearly laid out in such a way that the solution seems impossible until you figure out some clever trick. Instead, the game is a lot of "wander around, solve a simple mechanical exercise that can't really be called a puzzle, wander around some more, oh the look a random end of the level". I haven't run into anything I could call a puzzle, more just tech demos for the gameplay elements, and the fact that the gate that takes you to the next level is always just around some random corner after one of these mechanical challenges makes it hard to be interested in progression. Any time I got stuck it was because of red herrings or something important being hidden in an alcove in the ceiling, which are filler elements we shouldn't see in puzzle games in 2015.

tl;dr, whoever made the game world did a fantastic job, whoever made the puzzles should spend 20 hours playing the top-rated maps in Portal 2's map maker.
 
Spacesuit Spiff
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 février 2015
lovely game with lovely graphics and a lovely soundtrack/sfx. so far i haven't found any puzzles to be hard, but i haven't completed the game yet, either. i find it relaxing to focus on and fun to play. puzzle games can be pretty subjective-- in my opinion this isn't exactly challenging, but i'm alright with that because it's enjoyable anyway. new things are continually introduced to keep things different between "worlds".

make sure you have time set aside to fully complete a level, though. exiting the game erases all progress within a level regardless of save points. if you're the type to have to get up or leave the computer at the drop of the hat during the middle of something, this game can get a little frustrating.

Recommandé
38.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 février 2015
Ein sehr schönes Spiel.
Es verbreitet eine geheimnisvolle Stimmung, die noch durch den Umstand verstärkt wird, dass es im Spiel selbst keine Anleitung gibt. Man muss also die Spielmechanik selbst erforschen.

Das Spiel ist in Weltenwürfeln mit je sechs Leveln aufgeteilt.
Es sieht für mich so aus, dass pro Weltenwürfel eine neue Funktion hinzukommt, die das Spiel dann auch komplexer und fordernder mach.
Wieviele dieser Weltenwürfel es gibt, kann ich nicht mit Bestimmtheit sagen, nach den Steam-Achievements zu urteilen sieht es so aus, das es sechs Weltenwürfel sein könnten. Das wären also 36 Level.
Schon gespielte Level kann man jederzeit wiederholen, um auch die letzten Geheimnisse zu lüften und so mehr Steam-Achievements freizuschalten.

Speichern kann man in den Leveln nicht selbst.
Durch "Speicher-Statuen" werden automatische Checkpoints erstellt, an denen man wieder aufgesetzt wird, falls man abgestürzt ist.

Ich bin nach 4,5 Stunden auf dem zweiten Level des dritten Weltenwürfels gelangt.
Das Spiel wird nun deutlich komplexer und macht mir noch immer sehr viel Spaß.
 
JoeSlow
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
16.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 février 2015
Qbeh is a puzzle platformer that does not disappoint. You pick up colored cubes to place in marked positions in the map. You'll build small bridges and stairs out of these cubes to get to the next area, and, when you discover the other types of cubes, you'll be making low grav jumpways and riding cubes over precarious pits.

The experience is just like the music in the game -- relaxing and beautiful. If you're looking for a thrillride or a sarcastic, witty narrator, this isn't your game.

If you'd like to relax, figure out some puzzles at your own pace, this is a great game. If you're like me, you'll be hoarding cubes in an effort to break out of the map and discover secrets. This game does not disappoint in this respect either.

I really enjoyed every second of this game and didn't want it to end. I can't recommend this game enough.

The first puzzle platformer I've ever played where the character runs.

Well, jokes aside, this puzzle platformer revolves around cubes, cubes, cubes, and more cubes. These cubes can be used as platform extesions or switches that causes some events in the stage like opening doors, moving platforms, etc. The terrain looks calming for me but may look bland for others. Nonetheless, I got a good experience from this, so I'd like to recommend this game.

Évaluation publiée le 24 décembre 2014
At first when I saw this game I thought it would be another voxel-minecraft-wanabe-puzzle-cheap game. I was so wrong, first the only similarity between this and minecraft was the main shape of the game: a cube. The graphics are supprisingly good and run well on my Asus r510c. The simplicty of the game makes it so good, there is absolutely no need for a tutoral and doesn't overcomplicate the begining with dumb-filler-nobodycaresabout-exposition. Rather it lures you in with mystery. I have still yet to play the game through but from what I've seen in a mere 54 minutes is awesome.

The name "Qbeh-1" is hopefully insinuating a second.

Overall 9.9999/10
reason: the .00001 deduction is because the trees glitch out, the textures for some reason are plauged with black lines.

36.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 décembre 2014
Fantastic Cube Puzzle Game with optional exploring (find some pyramids and special rooms in hard accessible areas).
I really like the idea of different coloured cubes with various functionality.
It`s always fair, not to hard, not to easy. Imo some savepoints should have been set different, but overall it seems pretty fair. Jumping can be tricky from time to time.
If you find all pyramids in world 1 to 5 (each has 6 levels, so in total 30 levels), world 6 (with 6 more levels) will be unlocked. 36 levels in total with easily over 10 hours playing time is really nice for this price.
9/10 for me

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
23.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 novembre 2014
On va pas tourner autour du pot. C'est un très bon jeu.

Ce qui fait son charme c'est surtout son ambiance. C'est beau, on est dans les nuages, le moteur graphique permet des éclairages réalistes et très sympa. Surtout pour les niveaux au crépuscule. J'ai aussi beaucoup aimé l'architecture des niveaux entre temples et labyrinthes, on peut kiffer rien qu'a se balader.
Les musiques sont piles dans l'esprit du jeu, calme, relaxantes, parfois certaines sonorités rajoutent une touche de frissons et de mystère.
C'est un puzzle game bien pensé avec une durée de vie très honnorable. 5 mondes de 6 niveaux chacun se parcourent en une dizaine d'heures. Si vous voulez récupérer tout les tokens (bonus cachés dans chaque niveau) la durée de vie augmente d'autant. Il y a apparament un 6e monde que je n'ai pas encore débloqué. Donc toc ! une raison de plus d'essayer de trouver tous les tokens.

La difficulté est croissante et plutôt bien jaugée. Finir les niveaux vous demandera parfois un peu de jugeote et de réflexion mais vous ne serez jamais coincé. C'est pour trouver les tokens que vous devrez vous montrer plus malin. Soyez curieux et explorez chaque recoins.

Au moment où je l'ai acheté le jeu avait tendance à crasher fréquemment mais un patch est rapidement sortit et le jeu est maintenant stable.

Point important supplémentaire, Qbeh-1 est compatible Occulus Rift. Même si je n'ai pas pu le tester avec je pense que c'est typiquement le genre de jeu où l'imerssion fait son effet. Les possésseur et futur possésseurs de l'occulus auraient tord de passer à coté d'un ptit jeu comme celui là à moins de 10 euros, ne serait-ce que pour calibrer l'appareil.

Mais même avec un écran classique on se laisse porter sans difficulté dans ce soft envoutant.

Je pourrais lui chercher des défauts, mais à quoi bon quand l'impression finale est très bonne et que le titre se vend pour moins de 10€ plein tarrif.

Laissez vous tenter. Ce jeu n'est pas une arnaque.
 
Pixel_Fourbe

4.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 septembre 2014
Qbeh-1？きゅうべえわん？タイトルの読み方が分からない。

まあ置いといて・・・
内容としては、ブロックを置いたり回収したりして障害物をクリアし、出口を目指すもの。
ゲーム的には中々面白く、癒され系のビジュアル・BGMも相まって長時間プレイしてしまうこと請け合い。

ブロックを置けるところは決まっているが、ステージ内で入手できるブロックの数は決まっており、どう置けば良いのか頭を使う。
ところどころ床が抜けていて、転落することも出てくるのだが、ペンギン風のチェックポイントを通過しないと最初からになるのは少々ストレスフル。

また、高設定でやると意外に重い。
GeforceまたはRadeonのミドルクラス以上は必要なのではないかと思う。

それからやや動作が不安定に思える。
メニュー画面で固まることがある。
 
samo1000

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
45.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 septembre 2014
I fully recommend Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube - it's been a long time since I've been that obsessed with carrying on in a game.

"First person 3D platform discovery puzzler" is how I'd sum up the game category. As such, the game is to some extent comparable to Antichamber and Portal, both of which I have been playing in recent months. There is even a reference to Portal hidden in one of the Qbeh-1 levels.

Despite Portal and Antichamber having more innovative game principles, of the three I enjoyed Qbeh-1 most.

As I see it, the beauty of Qbeh-1 stems from the level design, the atmosphere and ambience. It has the feel of discovering abandoned places of ancient cultures, with some left-over machinery such as doors to be opened with switch mechanisms, cube elevators and fans (ventilators). The background music perfectly enhances the visual impressions and the "exploration" feeling. It will change at some points within levels, for example upon entering impressive, awe-inspiring halls.

Qbeh-1 is linear in the sense that there is one level after another, each a place of its own, with its own theme, and separate from other levels.

What may seem odd at first, but really adds a lot to the atmosphere, is the fact that each individual level is located mid-air, sort of "in the clouds". You will often find yourself balancing on the brink of "abyss", and falling down is the main danger to be faced in many levels of the game. Due to cleverly placed checkpoints the game never feels frustrating. Many of the places feel like ruins, some of them crumbling under your feet.

Discovery is one of the main joys in the game: There are several surprises to be found within the levels, and finding special items hidden within the levels is part of what's needed to beat the game. So looking around closely to find non-obvious paths to progress on is essential in Qbeh-1. Often you'll find yourself "outdoors", or peeking outside hallways and halls, getting the tease of seeing parts of levels you want to progress to, and not knowing yet how to get there.

Your basic interaction with the world around you consists of running around and jumping, similar to most first person 3D games. Most other interactions are done by collecting cubes - there are different types scattered in the levels - and applying them in certain locations within the levels, sometimes to activate switches, sometimes to build bridges or to provide other means of getting to some place that would be unreachable without cubes. These "cube application puzzles" will rarely be intellectual challenges to spend hours on. However, there are often different ways of applying the cubes - it is a creative task with non-obvious solutions and surprising new paths.

Usually you have all the time in the world within the levels. There are only a few locations and challenges within the levels, such as elevator cubes and fans, where accurately timed jumps and cube placings are essential.

It feels really rewarding to reach parts of levels previously unreachable, often seeing levels from completely new angles, and often climbing incredible heights - face your vertigo!
 
ryd_darder
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 juillet 2014
Like exploration ? like puzzles ? like platforms ?
Well, then, trust me, you'll enjoy this game.
The environment is beautiful, the music is remaxing, the controls are very good.
Once we've said that, we already know we have a good game. Now, let's focus on contents.

Each world (there are five, containing 6 levels each) introduces a new cube with new abilities (red will stack with others, blue will activate switches ...). Basics are easy to pick up, mastering them might be a bit harder, but anyway the cdifficulty curve is pretty smooth.
Finishing the levels are more about puzzles and platform skills, but in each level there is an extra to find and to reach (reaching it can sometimes be pretty easy, but finding it can be difficult, even frustrating sometime). Well, that's the exploration part, and is is optional, so it's fine.

Some levels can be pretty long, but they all have a few checkpoints (despite that, in some levels, death can be quite the punishment).

All in all, that's a great game that I recommend. For me, its only weak point would be that it takes a little time to charge a level, but it won't stop you from having hours of fun playing this game.
 
foxclear

Highly recommend this intuitive platform-puzzler with a great variety in difficulty. Relaxing and stimulating soundtrack coupled with beautiful graphics. Has a linear solution, but is open for some creative platforming which makes it even more fun to try out each course again. Very few bugs and glitches makes this a well polished game, despite it's rather fresh state.

If you are a fan of 3D platformers or puzzle games where you have to check your surroundings carefully, check this game out!

Recommandé
26.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 juin 2014
I've got to say, I rarely write reviews for anything, but I think that in this case, I just have to. So let's get started!

A quick intro

Qbeh-1 is a prequel to game Qbeh (which you can download via Desura). Qbeh was a student project, practically a demo containing 6 levels. This '-1' (minus one) standing next to Qbeh tells that this is a prequel. So, getting back to Qbeh-1: This is a first person perspective non-violent exploration puzzle platformer game. You will meet several game genres here.

What you can expect
The game contains 5 (or maybe 6? I won't spoil it) worlds, each with 6 levels.
It's an exploration game, so you will not be told practically anything except key bindings (in options).

a) Your goal

Your goal is simple: find the portal to the next level. Simple but difficult.

b) Environment

As you probably saw in the trailers, Qbeh-1 is inspired by Minecraft - almost everything is made of cubes. In every level, you will be placed in... well, locations floating somewhere high in the sky. The sky is both above you and below you. On your way, you will encounter several kinds of cubes you can pick up, each one with a unique ability.

c) No violence

For some it's an advantage, for some it's a disadvantage. The only dangers you face is falling, being crushed by a door and touching poison.

d) Soundtrack

Soundtrack of Qbeh-1 is what makes the game incredible. It's ambient, atmospheric, soothing, relaxing... Each level has different soundtrack, and every song creates a different climate. You will definetly like it.

e) Pace
The game is rather slow-paced, but if you don't like it, in one of the worlds you will encounter fans, transporting you at high speeds.

f) Gameplay

I forgot to mention about this at the beginning of my review, sorry ;)
As I said before, you can pick up special cubes (several kinds) you can then place on special surfaces or other cubes. The game gives you the freedom of building, so there are always several ways to solve each puzzle. On each level, you can also find a Secret Token, and if you collect them all, you will unlock something special.

Overall

Qbeh-1: The Atlas Cube is a relaxing game, you can have a break from reality. You will have to jump, think, explore and have good eyesight.
It's now on sale, so I fully recommend you to buy it. Buy, and you will not regret.



Thank you for reading :)

16.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 juin 2014
GUYS
GUYS
I JUST GLITCHED IN LEVEL 4-1
I'M IN A PERMANENT LOW-GRAVITY EFFECT WITHOUT BEING IN A LOW-GRAVITY CUBE ZONE
I CAN GO ALMOST ANYWHERE NOW
THIS FEELING OF FREEDOM
Ahem. In all seriousness, while I've only gotten to level 4-1, I must say I'm really quite impressed with the atmosphere. One level in particular stood out for me: 2-3, Monolith. The fog combined with the music gave me chills the entire time.
I should note, though, that the level design hasn't been playtested thoroughly. So far in every level except 2-3 (and to some extent 3-6) I have managed to somehow get myself outside the area that the player is intended to play within, all using only the mechanics provided to me. Backtracking once I have more cubes often allows me to climb out the top of the "expressive" area that I am meant to play in, and out into the areas with flat, featureless exteriors. On 2-2, you can even see pieces of models sticking up out of the roof you're standing on, icicles and snow hanging in midair because the rest of it is being used as interior decoration. That said, this is still a really good game, possibly BECAUSE it gives you the freedom to do such things.
In short, I love this game despite its quirks, because those quirks just expand what the player can accomplish.
 
failure face

Évaluation publiée le 2 juin 2014
I have been waiting for the release of this game after playing the original Qbeh game made by Liquid Flower. I must say, I truly cant critisize the game, its amazing! The level design and sounds are incredible. Definately worth my £7 :) Hats off to Toni Räsänen, Jussi Tuomi, Mika Karkinen and Joost Kraaijenbrink for making the game! If you want to watch a gameplay of this, or your stuck on a level, then watch my playthrough of this to help :)

3.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 mai 2014
Upon writing this review, I've only been playing the game for about an hour - already, I simply adore it. The incredible serenity of the game is enough to make me feel entirely content just walking around and experiencing the beautifully calming atmosphere and music - and if there're two things I absolutely love in games like this, it's well-established atmosphere and music.

The texturing in Qbeh-1 is really lovely too. I'm genuinely impressed with the simplicity of the surroundings, yet also with how intriguing and gorgeous they are. One thing I would especially love to mention is the wonderful view you receive from these mysterious skybound islands when you look out off a clear edge and observe the skyline, clouds, and seemingly distant world below. On top of that, the gameplay is absolutely lovely, and the controls are solid and pleasant to use. I recommend this game to anyone who digs Indie titles with serene atmospheres, beautiful soundtracks, and peaceful - yet relatively simplistic - puzzles.

... Did I mention that the music is absolutely gorgeous?~
 
Clown Husband

Recommandé
25.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 mai 2014
Qbeh-1 is a beautiful, peaceful and hauntingly still game with a feeling of ancient isolation that washes over you like an ocean breeze. No harm can come to you here, and there is no rush to make anything happen. It is all a matter of enjoying yourself. The worlds of Qbeh-1 are like Myst ages for the retired archaeologist, like the planet Risa for the weary dungeon puzzler, like Robinson Crusoe with none of the threats to survival. You begin to get the sense that this place has been lived in many times before, but that it still has secret knowledge to reveal. This game is an escape and a release from the stress of other times and places. I go here to breathe.
 
serpentdav

I love this game. The setting is beautiful, the music is serene, and the puzzles are very entertaining. It is perfect for both short bursts or extended playing.

Even in the short amount of time I've spent with it so far the puzzles have been getting increasingly more engaging and I love being able to find the hidden pyramid in each stage (I feel so clever when I do).

5/5

Évaluation publiée le 26 mai 2014
So much cursing and rage quitting, but also never made happier by cubes before in my life. Really mind-bending, and beautiful atmosphere and environment.

The parallels with Portal are obvious, but Qbeh holds its own as a very satisfying, really challenging puzzle game.
